business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) condemns the decision of the Bush Administration to impose tariffs and quotas on Australian steel imports;
(2) welcomes the recent backdown on the import of hot rolled coil;
(3) recognises that the US decision makes a mockery of the Administration's free trade rhetoric; and
(4) indicates deep concern about the impact of the decision on:
(a) employment levels within the steel industry and in the coal and iron ore sectors; and
(b) the dumping of increased volumes of surplus steel.

I take this opportunity to speak in support of the motion standing in my name on behalf of the many thousands of workers and their families in my electorate of Throsby whose wellbeing depends very much on the ongoing viability of our domestic steel making capacity. The Port Kembla steelworks is the largest employer in my electorate with an estimated 10,000 direct and indirect jobs relying on it. The steelworks inject about $1.4 billion into our own regional economy annually and much of the product that is produced at Port Kembla has been finding its way into international markets.

Following a lot of heart wrenching, pain and agony in the 1980s and 1990s, and after a downturn of full-time employment opportunities and the loss of probably up to 20,000 jobs at the steelworks, I am pleased to say that we now have a committed work force, together with an enterprising management that saw the need to invest capital in the plant. We now have a steelworks in my electorate which is one of the most efficient and productive steelworks in the whole world. I think the families and the workers who I represent in that electorate are mightily proud of their achievement and their efforts.

In that context, the families and work force in my electorateâhaving gone through a lot of pain in the 1980s and 1990sâwere absolutely shocked when word first came out that the United States administration was considering the imposition of tariffs and quotas on steel that was exported from our steelworks and found entry into the US markets. They were shocked because they believed that the changes that had seen the transformation of the steel industry locally meant that we would be competing as efficient and productive producers on a level playing field. Little did they expect that the country that leads the rhetoric in terms of free trade was going to turn around and reinstitute trade barriers, making it so much more difficult for efficient and productive producers like our own steel industry to get a foothold in that market.

The workers and their families believe that the United States decision is hypocritical, and it flies in the face of the constant appeals that we have heard from the United States about the benefits of free trade. It seems that they extol the virtues of free trade except when it impinges on their domestic industries, as we have seen over the years in terms of the agricultural subsidies and more recently in terms of what we consider to be a wrong decision in principle. This is a wrong decision because it impacts negatively on steelworks like the Port Kembla steelworks that have gone through a massive reorganisation and transformation to come out at the other end as efficient and productive steel producers.

Naturally, the local people were very concerned about the decision which mooted that quotas and tariffs would be imposed on Australian steel imports. We were very worried locally because currently about 800,000 tonnes of steel is exported from Port Kembla, worth in the vicinity of $400 million to $450 million in exports to the United States, predominantly to west coast mills. So you can understand the concerns of the local community because the steelworks is so much the heart and soul of the economic viability of the Illawarra region and of my electorate in particular.

The government did take some credit in that, following negotiations, exemptions were procured for our slab product but then later onâand after a bit more arm wrenching and arm twistingâthe local people were relieved to learn that the hot rolled coil predominantly used by Steelscape, a former BHP subsidiary, was also to be exempt from the quota and tariff regime. So while we are pleased that 85 per cent of export volumes appear at this stage to be exempt, around $100 million in export sales in our judgment are still very much under threat. While not professing to be an expert in trade mattersâDr Martin will no doubt speak about those implications in seconding this motionâwe are still not in a situation where all our product, produced efficiently, competitively and productively, is exempt from the trade restrictions being imposed by the United States administration.

The motion I am proposing condemns the United States decision, firstly, because it makes a mockery of their adherence to free trade; secondly, because it is punitive and punishes, in particular, efficient and productive producers of steel; and, thirdly, because, even though we might say that 85 per cent of our export volumes appear to be exempt, it will of necessity have a negative impact on the Australian domestic steel industry. It will have a negative impact in two ways. I do not think anyone is in a position as yet to quantify the direct negative impact on employment within the steel industry but, beyond that, it can well lead to a very marked negative impact on our iron ore and coal sectors. Because of the glut of steel in the world market, it may be that decisions to wind back production in certain countries will have a multiplier effect on employment levels domestically in our coal and iron ore sectors. Beyond that, I think we need to bear in mind that the Australian steel industry, in terms of employment levels, has been hit very hard. An estimated 30 per cent of steel industry jobs were lost in the 1990s and almost 90,000 manufacturing jobs have disappeared since 1997, so it is not the time for the government to sit back and merely react to the decisions made by the US administration.

We know that increased volumes of surplus steel are likely to be dumped in Australia and we know from previous arguments in this chamberâarguments led by my colleague the member for Lyons about the inadequacy of current dumping proceduresâ that it will not be too far down the track before efficient and productive domestic producers will be facing the impact of steel being dumped at dumped prices here in Australia. A summit was called by the government but, much to the shame of the government, they wanted to play petty politics and excluded from that summit the shadow ministers for trade and industry and the elected representatives of the steel making towns of Throsby, Newcastle and Wollongong.

In winding up my comments, my plea is for this government to be far more proactive in terms of our domestic steel industry, not to sit back and react when the US and other countries decide to do what they perceive is in their domestic interest but to actually have a proactive, supportive industry framework that understands the implications of this current decision and the likely negative consequences. In that regard, I draw to the attention of the chamber the fact that one of my local employers, Onesteelâwhich is currently wishing to tender for the SEA Gas project, producing pipes for the Victoria to South Australia gas pipelineâis very concerned that external bidders might be bidding on the basis of dumping cheap product here in Australia. The government needs to get its act together, needs to tighten up the monitoring of imported steel, needs to make sure that dumping processes can be accessed and prosecuted expeditiously and, lastly and most importantly, needs a framework of positive industry support for our vital and critical domestic steel industry.

talk.start.para: âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âIt gives me great pleasure to address the issues raised in the motion and to agree with the vast bulk of them and, in particular, with the terms of the motion. I represent the electorate of Flinders. The Westernport steelworks, which is soon to be spun off as part of the creation of BHP Steel, is in this electorate. Westernport generates over 1,400 jobs; it employs steelworkers from throughout the electorate; it contributes over $30 million in wages alone to people on the Mornington Peninsula; and it contributes over $20 million in expenditure on the Mornington Peninsula. It is the largest employer, it is a key contributor to the community and it is an important element in the life and times of the Mornington Peninsula.

speech.para: In that context, I wish to make three points about the United States decision and about this motion in particular. The first is that the US decision was clearly wrong. It was a betrayal of the US obligations under its World Trade Organisation responsibilities and it was a betrayal of its obligations to Australia as a genuine and committed free trader. Second, I wish to make the point that, despite this decision, the Australian government achieved a remarkably strong outcomeâ stronger than almost any other country in the world and one which protected and enhanced the position of Australian steelworkersâbut there is still more to be done. Third, I wish to add to the points made by the member for Throsby: arguably the greatest threat to Australian steelworkers, who have already achieved through themselves and through management an almost unparalleled level of efficiency in global steel markets, is the actions of certain members of union leadership. I will set out some of the evidence for that.

The first point is that the US decision of 6 March to restrict steel imports through quotas and tariffs of up to 30 per cent flies squarely in the face of the US World Trade Organisation obligations. The implications are threefold. Firstly, the tariffs and quotas are unfairly restrictive and impact on the unsubsidised Australian product. It attacks the very people whom the US is trying to encourageâand that is an industry of over $A450 million in annual steel exports to the United States. The second problem with the US decision is that it destabilises the world market for steel, potentially causing large volumes of low-priced steel to circulate on international markets. That is whyâand I will come back to thisâanyone who would potentially support this US decision is in fact threatening Australian jobs. We will ask ourselves: who supported the US decision? The third problem is with the US decision is that it sends a signal that the United States is less than fully committed to advancing more open international trade, and that is accompanied by the US decision on the farm bill, which also has an implication for Australian farmers and agricultural producers. For all those reasons, it was simply a bad decision and a wrong decision.

More importantly, what has the Australian government done to both anticipate and respond to the decision? Firstly, the coalition government worked very hard prior to any US decision because it was understood that under section 201 the US government was looking at actions on steel. The government worked with Australian exporters to achieve a 50 per cent exclusion of Australia's total steel exportsâAustralian slab steel exportsâwhich were not affected by the initial import restrictions. That was a good outcome, but there was still a lot more to be done, and that was prior to the US decision. Subsequent to the US decision, after President Bush's 6 March announcement, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources and Australia's Ambassador to the United States, Michael Thawley, along with others, worked extraordinarily hard to achieve a second wave of concessions for Australian steel. A further 35 per cent of our exports to the United States, being hot rolled coil, as mentioned in the motion moved by the member for Throsby, was excluded from the 30 per cent tariff ceiling. The result was that 85 per cent of Australian steel was excluded. That was a good outcome, but there is more to be done. Until 100 per cent is excluded we are not going to rest.

The interesting thing is that there is also the risk, as was set out by the previous speaker, that there might be the problem of dumping on the Australian steel market. That is a real problem. What is the government doing on that front? The Minister for Trade, the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources and the Minister for Justice and Customs have established a task force and working group on dumping. They have representatives of not only Australian steel exporters but also the Australian Industry Group and the Australian Workers Union. The whole industryâworkers and managementâare involved in working to protect Australia from dumping as a flow-on. But here is where the real twist comes in: you would imagine that if there were a threat to jobs, the union leadership would have been opposed to it. I bring to the attention of the House an article in the Hastings Independentâa good local newspaper, if I may say soâof 12 March 2002. The headline was `Steelworkers back US tariffs'. The article begins:

quote.para: The Western Port Steel workers are getting the word not to blame the United States for its steel tariffs. `Good on you, Yanks' is more like it according to Australian Workers Union State President Mick Eagles.

speech.para: That is the message from the Australian Workers Union State President, Mick Eagles. Will the member for Throsby and the member for Cunningham support or denounce that position? The article goes on to quote Mr Eagles as saying:

quote.para: We congratulate them on these tariffs.

speech.para: It gets worse: the union not only welcomed the US decision but also actively worked towards it. The article continues:

quote.para: Geoff Cooney, union organiser at the BHP plant, was at the International Metals Federation meeting of steelmakers in Washington 2000.
`It was resolved to stop dumping of the cheap steel in members markets,' Mr Cooney said.

speech.para: Mick Eagles said:

quote.para: The American steel workers have now struck the first blow.

speech.para: The union not only endorsed the decision of the United States to introduce steel tariffs at the expense of Australian workers but also actively worked towards it. That is an extraordinary decision which puts at risk jobs in Cunningham, Throsby, Flinders and Paterson. In all those areas there is a risk from the very action which the union leaders have taken. But why would they do that? What is the mentality behind it? I continue with the article entitled `Steelworkers back US tariffs' in the Hastings Independent of 12 March 2002, six days after the US decision was announced:

quote.para: Heâ

speech.para: Mick Eaglesâ

quote.para: said a ... decline in Port Kembla steel sales to the United States was not the main risk. `The danger is dumping. Makers of cheap steel, like Turkey, Russia and China, losing their American markets, would then try and dump on Australia.'

speech.para: But here is the flaw in the logic: they prevent the export of steel to the United States by arguing for the US to impose steel tariffs, which in turn creates the risk of dumping, which in turn creates the problem for the Australian market, and then they complain that there might be a risk of dumping on Australian markets. It is extraordinary! They create the very risk of dumping and then they complain about it. Finally, there is the sheer hubris of the AWU position as set out by Mr Eagles himself, who goes on to say:

quote.para: All it's about, this globalisation, is making the greatest profits at the cheapest cost centres.

speech.para: The problem for Mr Eagles is that Australian steel makers are already some of the cheapest cost centres and most efficient producers in the world. Had it not been for the work of the government and its officials, perhaps 100 per cent of Australian steel would be exposed. Instead, it is now down to 15 per cent, which is still too high. That is why we aggressively fought for Australian steel jobs, and we did it without the help of the AWU's Victorian leadership, which actively fought to impose tariffs on US steel, which in turn imposed tariffs on Australian workers and put at risk the very jobs which all of us in this House would seek to protect and encourage. I am happy to ally myself with the motion and endorse its terms but it is critical that we look to the fact thatâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI support the motion moved by my friend and colleague the member for Throsby and I support the comments that she and the member for Flinders have made. When looking at the decision taken by the United States and the effect that it has had on Australia, what has been said so far has been dead right: it is a betrayal of the basic tenets of the World Trade Organisation's principles and it makes a mockery of the United States rhetoric about their commitment to free trade.

speech.para: When the Prime Minister gets to Washington next week, he has said that he is going to lecture the Congress and the Senate about how dreadful some of the things are that the US government is imposing and which are bringing into question their commitment to free trade. I hope he does not concentrate on agriculture. I hopeâand I hope that the member for Flinders will take this message to his Prime Ministerâthat he reruns this question about steel tariffs.

However, I cannot agree with the member for Flinders when he said that the government has achieved a strong outcome. As the member for Throsby so rightly said in her contribution, there is an 85 per cent exemption. That is true and, on the face of it, you would think that $400 million per year in value of exports into the United States by Australian steel producers with an 85 per cent outcome was reasonable, but it is not because the tariffs that are still imposed by the United States are at the high value end of the production. It is going to cost $100 million in terms of Australian steel producers' exports. That is one-quarter of an annual export earning capability of BHP and others from Australia into the United States which is now in danger. Is that a good outcome? I think not.

While the honourable member for Flinders is patting himself and his government on the back, I suggest that he ask the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Foreign Affairs that, if they saw this coming so long ago, how come that outcome came about? If they were out there lobbying on behalf of Australian manufacturing industry, how did this outcome come about? We see a lot of commitment and talk from the Minister for Trade when he is talking about agricultural subsidies, but then again he has a National Party constituency that he has to suck up to. However, the deal gets done.

As a great friend of the United States, we put our hand up and we were the first over there in Afghanistan beside them, but when we want some economic benefit to come from our great ally, what do we get? Absolutely nothing. What we get out of it is a kick in the behind. We have seen it in steel and we have seen it in the US farm subsidies bill.

What else do we see as a result of this decision? We now see the portents of a trade war. The European Union and Japan are already taking decisions through the WTO to take the United States to the WTO with an action to get these decisions on steel overturned. And well they might do that. Are we doing anything about that? Is the Australian government saying, `We'll join the European Union and Japan to protect Australian jobs because this decision by the United States is an absolute dud. It's against the WTO and against the interests of steel makers in this country.' Are we seeing the Australian government doing that? Is the Prime Minister even talking about doing that when he is over in Washington next week? The answer, sadly, is no. My constituents in Wollongong, the constituents of the member for Throsby and the constituents of the member for Flinders down at Western Port will be scratching their heads. They will be saying, `Hang on. How come our Prime Minister and the Minister for Trade aren't saying that? Why aren't they trying to prevent a trade war? Why aren't they saying through the WTO processes that we want to protect Australian jobs?'

The honourable member and the member for Throsby are dead right in respect of the real issue of dumping, and we have to look at that. Any measures the government takes to amend that level of concern have to be supported. However, at the end of the day, there is no doubt that employment questions are still going to be raised. There are questions about contributions by different people to the level of support. The honourable member for Flinders asked whether I would support the comments made by the Victorian division of the AWU on this. I would say noâunequivocally no because I think they got it wrong. However, they did not get it half as wrong as US President Bush and the United States administration in signing up to this dud proposition to protect the steel industry in the United States.

Their industry needs total reform. We did it here in 1983 under the Hawke government's steel industry plan and we have gone through a lot of pain in Newcastle, Wollongong and around Australia. It is about time the United States, the great defenders of this great concept of free trade, were out there practising what they preach. They should review this and the Prime Minister should get that review next week. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â Given the history of steel in the Hunter, I was particularly concerned when I saw the decision by the Bush administration on 6 March to restrict steel imports through quotas and tariffs of up to 30 per cent. In Australia, and particularly in the Hunter, we feel slighted by this US decision because we are a competitive producer of steel products and our industry has undergone the hard yards of restructuring. Through this restructuring, we have evolved into one of the most competitive producers of steel products in the world, and most importantly today, without any government subsidies.

speech.para: I am concerned that this tariff and quota protection implied by the Americans will affect $450 million in annual steel exports to the US and that this decision has destabilised the world market. What will this do to world steel prices? You might say that now that BHP has largely gone from the Hunter and as we basically only have a few steel rolling mills left, what effect would this have in the Hunter?

Quite simply, and it is no secret, three consortiums are looking at putting steelworks into the Hunter. They are the Austeel proposal, which is to be located at Tomago; Hunter Specialty steel, which is to be located at Lidell Power station; and Protech Steel, which is to go into Kooragang Island. All these decisions and the threat of a glut of cheap steel on the market affect the viability and the opportunity of these projects coming to my electorate to provide work for the thousands of people who have left the steel industry. As I said, BHP has been good to the Hunter over the years, but not in recent times. We need encouragement to invest.
I congratulate the Prime Minister and Minister Vaile on effectively getting an 85 per cent exemption. On 12 March, the Prime Minister said in this House:

quote.para: If you go back over all the difficult trade decisions that have been taken, adverse to the interests of this country, by the United States over the last 15 or 20 years, I cannot offhand recall one where, as a result of representations made by the government in power, the roll-back by the United States has been as great as it has been on this occasion.

speech.para: This government cares and is committed to free trade. However, let us have a look at the decisions and announcements by the Labor Party. Where has Simon Crean and the Creanites been on this? Today is relatively the first vocal decision we have seen except by members of the trade union movement, remembering that the trade union movement has a 60 per cent control over the Labor Party and therefore influences their decisions. The Victorian member of the Australian Workers Union, Mr Eagles, congratulated the US on its decision to impose tariffs. The US steelworkers union intervened to save US jobs, but what he does not understand is that this has the great potential to impact on Australian jobs.

Where are the Leader of the Opposition and the rest of the Creanites in supporting Australian jobs? We have heard today, for the first time, the member for Cunningham denouncing the announcement by Mr Eagles in Westernport; he does not agree with it. The reality is that this is a member of the unionâan official of the union movementâ who is a part of the Labor Party and who supports US introduction of tariffs to protect their jobs.

What we see from the Labor Party is a deep-seated desire to return to the days of protectionism, when we have achieved so much by opening up trade negotiations and decisions between countries that we deal with. As I said, my interest is to make sure that there are opportunities for companies like Hunter Specialty Steels, Protech and Austeel to set up here, to invest billions of dollars and to create the thousands of jobs which will bring money back into the Hunter. We do not want to see protectionism at any level because protectionism ultimately costs jobs.

We are a very competitive nation. I agree with what both the member for Throsby and the member for Cunningham have said; the Australian steel industry has done the hard yards and has paid the price and the penalties for taking these tough decisions. It is time we were given a competitive environment in which to put our products onto the world market. The steps taken by the Bush administration will effect that ability to a large extent.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for Paterson will have leave to continue his remarks when the debate is resumed.
âI move:

motion.para: That this House:

speech.para: (1) registers its concern about the escalating cost of public liability insurance, especially for smaller non-profit community groups;
(2) notes that a number of sporting and community groups indicate that further premium increases will curtail or end their activities in both urban and regional Australia; and
(3) calls on the Government to co-ordinate with State Governments urgent measures to cap claims and act against the litigious culture that contributes to high insurance premiums.

I am delighted to move the motion in the House today because this issue has been a major community issue throughout Australia. Members of this place and other state parliaments are now recognising this problem. Fundamentally, community groups are concerned about the outrageous and massive increases in public liability premiums. Community groups are approaching members of parliament on both sides expressing their concern that they cannot continue operating their particular local groups.

What is really the problemâas I have identifiedâis the number of claims, which have jumped from 55,000 in 1998 to 88,000 in 2000, a 60 per cent increase. The not-for-profit community groups cannot afford the insurance; tourism groups and other small businesses are having great difficulty handling the increased insurance premiums. I mention the local cricket clubs, country shows and progress associations in the electorate of Corangamite, such as the Bannockburn Golf Club, the Portarlington Development Association, the Maude Recreation Reserve, the Freshwater Creek Tennis Club, the Queenscliff Ozone Hotel View Grand, Gellibrand Hall, United Way and the Boorcan Cricket Club. These small commercial groups are run by volunteers and are having great difficulty paying their suggested premiums.

We need to identify what the causes are. Obviously one of the first causes is the litigious culture that has been developed by a number of the plaintiff lawyers. They have put up the proposition `no win, no fee' and that has encouraged a number of people to make claims. The advertising that has taken place has encouraged individual citizens to make claims that they otherwise would not have made.

In the time available, I would like to draw on a very interesting article and report by Mr Geoff Burrowes, producer of TheMan From Snowy River and Mansfield resident, which is in the heartland of the electorate of McEwen. I see that the parliamentary secretary is at the table. I will quote extensively from this article in the WeeklyTimes of 22 March 2002 because I think it will draw to the attention of the House and the community a very intelligent assessment of the problem. He states in this article:

quote.para: We've caused the problem, ripping off the system and going for the payout, looking for the main chance. We've laughed at the huge payouts and the ridiculous claims of fault. We've been disgusted by the pompous self promotion of lawyers, the demeaning of the law and the detachment of judges from the reality of life.

speech.para: That was his opening statement. I think many people in Mansfield and at the particular rally would agree with that. He goes on:

quote.para: It is the large number of small insurance claims that are the real problemâ94 per cent of claims are for minor injuries and make up 77 per cent of the claims payouts.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: For years we've smirked at the US as the world's most litigious society. But we've gone the same way, some would say we've even surpassed the US as a litigious nation.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: This rise in public liability insurance is an assault on small business, community groups, providers of adventure and experience.

speech.para: He goes on to talk about the people of Mansfieldâthe parliamentary secretary is a very vigorous advocate of the people of Mansfieldâand states:

quote.para: We are a people of the bush, the ocean, our rivers and mountains. Though most of us to live in the cities, we treasure our links to the outdoors, it's part of our self, or who we are. If we're cut off from the outdoors we cease to be Australians.
We all need to look at whether we're members of a community or individuals after a pot of gold.
We first need a generational shift in values, that people take greater responsibilities for their actions and lives.

speech.para: I think that is the key element of what he is saying: we need to be responsible for those many difficult tasks out there and not immediately seek the support of a lawyer. He goes on to say:

quote.para: The Mansfield proposal (using legislation to eliminate claims for minor injury while maintaining the victim's right to sue for damages in cases of serious injury involving negligence) can work.

speech.para: Basically, what Mr Burrowes is saying is that people have become greedy. They have seen the pot of gold. The whole public liability area has got out of control. Members of this parliament understand that and I am sure other members will support this very important proposal before the parliament.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI notice that my notice of motion, which was on the Notice Paper before this one, was not chosen for consideration. I am having a few problems getting my questions up as well as getting my notices of motions debated. But I congratulate the member for Corangamite on having his motion on the Notice Paper for us to discuss.

speech.para: Certainly, the federal government does not seem to be giving us much leadership at all in this area. The problem has been around for three years-plus. I picked it up about three years ago when a community group came to me about the local government asking them to cover themselves for public liability insurance for up to $10 million or they would have to leave the hall which they were using. I think I raised that on a previous occasion. In this case, 10 women in an embroidery group met every week and paid a dollar to help cover the cost of the lighting of the hall. They were then basically told that they would have to raise $450 a year to cover the insuranceâa ridiculous situation for those women, who had never had a claim. A small market at Epping in my electorate, which a lot of people would be familiar with, had enormous problems in raising a level of money for public liability insurance. That small market was started by a group of people that came together and decided to have a small market to raise money for the hall.

These are difficult circumstances for many small groups in our communities right across Australia. The problem is also the result of bad business practicesâby one insurance company for sureâand the business community taking fright from the large payouts from September 11. This is now taking its toll on our small communities, most of which have paid insurance for years and years and never had a claim of any sort, and we heard about some of those in the House last week. There is always the question of why the less advantaged in our community always end up paying the bill for those who are less scrupulous.

Really, the insurance industry stand condemned in Australia. They have let us get to this stage. Their industry has collapsed in this area. We know that the Liberal Party and the insurance industry are very close, and I think that might have had something to do with it. The minister might have failed the test as well. Members on the other side of the House laugh about this sort of thing, but it is that sort of complication that sometimes holds back reform, and it is well past time for reform of the insurance industry.

This is a federal government problem. It is a constitutional matter for the federal government, and they should be acting and showing leadership. They have to fix it. The insurance industry needs an enormous shake-up. It needs to get away from the business of speculation and get on with dealing with risk assessment and covering the actual needs of activities.

All of the money from the Bothwell races, which I think the member for Braddon mentioned last week, went into the community. That is another event that has been cancelled because of this very problem. Last year I put out a brochure based on information that we had gathered, trying to help groups to find insurance to minimise risk and look for umbrella groups so that they could get a quote. Some of them have been able to achieve that. It seems odd that there is not much publicity about last week's meeting down in Melbourne.

We really have to get back to fixing the harm. The person that has been injured should be fixed. Fixing the harm is what insurance is about. Let us get back to some basic principles about what insurance is and make some risk assessments about the activities that are going on. The insurance industry should be helping with that, and I do not see them doing that. I see this Liberal Party-insurance industry nexus which is failing the people of Australia. We need to act in a way which will help reunite those small communities and those events. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to second this motion and support my good friend and colleague the member for Corangamite. This is a very timely motion, and the points that he made were very worthwhile. As he put in the motion, there is `concern about the escalating cost of public liability insurance, especially for smaller non-profit community groups', there are `a number of sporting and community groups' that are going to have to `curtail or end their activities' if insurance premiums keep rising and there is a need for the Commonwealth and state governments to get involved.

speech.para: This is a very timely debate, given that the Commonwealth and state governments have got involved and are certainly moving. But there is no room for easing up on this. There is still an awful lot to be done. It is very disappointing to hear the member for Lyons come in here and try to oversimplify this debate and just try and blame it on the insurance companies. If he had taken half an interest in what has really been going on in the growth in litigation, the way some greedy lawyers have tried to exploit people's accidentsâand what better example could we have had than that one at Bondi a few weeks ago?âhe would have realised that it is not just insurance companies; there are a whole range of things that have to be addressed here. It is important that we get right behind the work that the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Coonan, has been doing, supported by a number of state governments which have recognised equally that there is a real problem.

Maybe the member for Lyons could just look around himself a little and see that there are even judges who are now admitting the problems that are involved with the courts. A good example is that two months ago in his retirement speech Justice James Thomas from the Queensland Supreme Court stated:

quote.para: We have allowed the tests for negligence to degenerate to such a trivial level that people can be successfully sued for ordinary human activity.

speech.para: Those are the sorts of points that have really got to be brought home. Former Chief Justice of the High Court Sir Harry Gibbs in an address about three weeks ago to a symposium of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering really hit the nail on the head with a number of comments that he made. I will pick out a few. In his introductory remarks, he pointed out:

quote.para: If the risk of injury or death had not been taken no one would have been able to travel in a railway train, a motor car or a jet aircraft, or to have an organ transplant or a cardiac pacemaker. Indeed, if risks of that kind had not been taken, Australia as we know it would not exist ... the voyage of discovery of Captain Cook and that of the First Fleet entailed great risk.

speech.para: One wonders how the lawyers would have lined up on that one. Sir Harry Gibbs made some other points that I think are very relevant. He said:

quote.para: The culture of litigation has been fostered by some lawyers who, whenever a mishap occurs, advertise for potential claimants and encourage them to sue or to join in a class action. These activities would once have been regarded as unprofessional but the former professional rules have been relaxed in the mistaken belief that it was more important to encourage competition than to maintain long established ethical standards. Some restrictions on advertising by lawyers have been reimposed. It would, however, be too much to hope that any ban on advertising or touting for work by lawyers would change the culture of blame which is now well established in society. The lawyers jumped on the bandwagon.

speech.para: He made many other comments, which I might come back to if I have time. I will read a letter that was sent to me in my electorate. It sums up the real problems that we are facing in local communities, particularly in the country. It says:

quote.para: To whom it may concern.
The Members of the Coleraine Youth Club wish to express their strong objection to the rise in Public Liability Insurance on Non Profit Organizations throughout the Country.

Our Club has supplied a low cost venue to Children of low income families for over 50 years and we feel that if there is any substantial increase in insurance etc. our fees will have to increase, therefore putting it out of reach of these families and the only solution will be too close our hall and put the children on the streets.

speech.para: I could go on and on about things that are happening at pony clubs and at all sorts of local community groups which are run by volunteers and provide part of the core of our local communities. This has become the No. 1 issue that we really have to face at both the community level and at the federal and state government level. I have great delight in supporting this motion of the member for Corangamite and I think it is very timely. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhilst congratulating the member for Corangamite on his motion, I note that it is somewhat ironic that the member for Corangamite should move a motion that calls on the government of which he is a member to act to resolve the crisis in public liability insurance. And why? The opposition has been calling on the government to do the very same thing for some time, but on each occasion we have been criticised for doing so.

speech.para: The Commonwealth government has been inept in its handling of this very serious issue. It has been clear for some time that the trend of public liability insurance was taking business and community organisations towards crisis. Spiralling insurance premiums or the absence of insurance coverage has threatened the viability of a growing number of businesses and community groups. Individuals have been hesitant to volunteer their participation in activities in their communities for fear of being sued in the event of an accident. Such a situation should be the responsibility of the Commonwealth government. The Commonwealth government should have recognised the severity of this situation and acted decisively to coordinate its resolution.

When RSL clubs were having to consider cancelling Anzac Day services, surely the Commonwealth government should have recognised that it was time to get serious. Instead, we saw confusion and inaction from the Commonwealth government. Treasurer Costello and Minister Coonan were saying one thing; minister Hockey was saying another. The sum total of his response was to suggest that state governments should get back into running insurance companies. Small business operators around Australia should be justifiably alarmed at the extent to which Minister Hockey takes an interest in dealing with issues that affect them.

It took state Labor governments to lead the way and propose measures to respond to this crisis. We should congratulate Premiers Gallop, Carr and Bracks for their leadership in bringing about reforms which may resolve the situation. The tort law reforms proposed at last week's national public liability summit are a sensible mechanism for ensuring small businesses and community organisations can remain in operation and access public liability insurance. They are part of a range of practical measures to deal with this issue.

One area where the Commonwealth did not go far enough was its failure to give the ACCC price exploitation powers over insurance in the same way as was done when the GST was introduced. Last week's summit provided the ACCC with the ability only to monitor market developments and premium prices, with a review of the ACCC's involvement in the future. The Commonwealth government should not wait and see if the insurance industry adjusts its premiums to take account of likely cost savings. It should take steps immediately to give the ACCC sufficient powers to deal with any insurance companies who are profiteering. After all, if it was necessary to protect consumers when the GST was introduced, why not small business and community organisations now?

The second area in which the Commonwealth government's response is lacking is in providing guarantees that state Liberal oppositions will support measures implemented by state Labor governments. This is not the time for state Liberal oppositions to be scoring cheap political points by holding up legislative reforms. It is the time to support the passage of legislative reforms so that this crisis becomes no worse. The Commonwealth government should give a commitment that it will fight to ensure state oppositions do not impede the reform process or hold it up purely for political gain.

Small business is the backbone of our economy. Community groups, sporting bodies and non-profit organisations make an enormous contribution to the fabric of our society. We have an obligation to act to ensure their ongoing viability is not compromised. We have heard that numerous businesses, clubs and organisations are faced with ruin through this particular problem. I would like to refer to one example in my electorate. It is a small family based company that has been around for many years. All they do is hire out camping equipment so that people can go away with their families for the weekend. They have been in business for something like 20 years, and in 12 years they have never made the slightest claim. Their premiums have gone up by about 300 or 400 per cent. They have told me that they will have to close their doors because they just cannot afford it. When this sort of situation is happening, it is clear that the government need to act. They have to do something decisively, and we need to deal with it as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: âIt seems that almost every day the newspapers have a tale to tell about another organisation facing the wall over billowing insurance costs. My first real indication of the growing crisis was the annual Blessing of the Fleet Festival in Ulladulla. The prospects seemed insurmountable at first but luckily, with everyone becoming involved, the matter was overcome, though at a greatly inflated cost. One of the issues that surfaced was the effect of statutory requirements adding to the costs for the associationâthat is, the need to ensure that certain things have been done to `cotton-wool' people against risk. If the organisation were to ignore any part of this minefield of bureaucracy, they would most likely void their insurance cover. This just means extra costs. In this case, it revolved around the need to appoint qualified traffic marshals.

speech.para: When the insurance issue broke following the collapse of HIH, I sent out a survey to all sporting and community groups in the Shoalhaven. I needed to gauge the effect and its impact on these groups and to see whether there was anything that could be done to assist. The response was overwhelming. Almost a 70 per cent response rate showed that all were experiencing a degree of difficulty, ranging from a slight inconvenience to absolute disaster.

What I also found surprising was the number of groupsâsmall groupsâthat had no insurance cover at all. This was despite the fact that legislation in New South Wales requires all such groups to be formed into incorporated associations to protect their members. That some were unaware of the legislation, or chose to ignore it, is particularly worrying in this climate of litigation and damages. Many of these groups were at the crossroads of deciding whether they could afford the cover being asked, which had jumped by between 50 and 500 per cent in many cases. In fact, some groups have already shut down because they could not pay the premiums.

Many residents of my electorate are members of such groups. They are members because the groups or associations offer them a means of social expression and enjoyment in something they like. Many are volunteers, because that is the Australian way. I refer of course to organisations like Meals on Wheels, St Vincent de Paul, the Red Cross Society, the Smith Family, volunteer bushfire brigades, the emergency services and many other charitable groups that help out in our community. If they were to withdraw their services because they could not afford the premiums, where would that leave not only the government but, most of all, the community they serve?

At the same time as the media stories started emerging of non-profit groups facing the shock of their insurance costs, there were also stories of huge court payouts for damages. To the man in the street, some of these are beyond belief and even people who are reasonably informed are questioning whether the courts are in touch with reality. In preparing my paper, I came across an article in the Daily Telegraph of 21 May questioning a payout of $3.75 million for a neck injury suffered in the surf. It is beyond comprehension how the decision can be justified, and that is just one. As an ordinary person, I have a notion of what I consider right and wrong, fair and equitableânatural justice, if you like. I also know that someone has to pay for it. From my perspective, what is developing here is neither fair nor equitable nor indeed even reasonable.

The other element that people are talking about is how much responsibility an individual should assume for their own actions and lack of care. It seems that governments today are relieving individuals of some of their obligations and foisting them onto the taxpayer. Maybe it is time that the principles underpinning common law were revisited. It is clear that public opinion sees the courts as out of step with community standards. I am heartened by the response of the state governments, at least in New South Wales, in legislating to contain these costs but I will wait until I have seen the detail. The ball is, after all, in their court, as state governments require organisations to be incorporated and to maintain adequate insurance coverage for their members. Perhaps it is time we started to accept individual responsibility for our own actions as opposed to the increasing inclination of looking out for No. 1.

Whatever steps we take now, it will take some time to filter through in any meaningful way. The federal government has a role to play in ensuring that some sort of uniformity applies across the board. The response has to be nationwide, for the insurers are not contained by state borders or international borders. Therein lies the problem. If premiums were based purely on claims experience, I am sure the premiums afforded these non-profit organisations would be minimal. However, the insurance industry requires the risk to be spread throughout their client base and so, inadvertently, innocent bystanders are paying the price for the mistakes of others. Why should I as a hockey player, a tennis player or a volunteer with Meals on Wheels be compelled to pay a premium that does not reflect the risk that I am exposed to? Even from the perspective of the Surf Life Saving Association, why do they have to pay just because they were on voluntary duty? The people of Australia do not want to know whose fault it is; they want it fixed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe lack of availability and the high cost of public liability insurance are issues that are threatening to cripple communities around this country and throughout my electorate. Volunteers will be restrained from coming forward to share their skills, and communities will fail for lack of members prepared to shoulder the burden of public liability insurance. Everyone in this debate has spoken of the massive increases in premiums, ranging from 100 per cent to 500 per cent, yet hardly anyone talks of the massive increases in excesses being levied by insurance companies. If an organisation scrapes the money together for the premium, they may have to pay the first $25,000 of a claim. I ask: how many organisations have a spare $25,000 to keep aside for a potential claim, and who is sued next for the excess if the organisation does not have the money? Committee members or board members, that is who.

speech.para: Additionally, within many of the groups there are coaches and specialists who need professional indemnity insurance. It is not just doctors who have a problem in this area. Professional indemnity and public liability have to be linked in any discussion of the problem. More importantly, we need to discuss the behaviour of the insurance industry, certainly in more detail than proposed by the meeting of state and federal governments last Thursday. At the meeting there were resolutions; but there will be no tort reform, just a review of market pricing every six months for the next two years. I would argue that we need a detailed inquiry now; we need action now; we need insurance cover now for the communities and the community organisations.

It is clear that insurance companies are planning to make money out of the low-risk organisations by increasing their premiums by, as I said, between 100 and 500 per cent. The high-risk organisations are being told that they will not be covered or are being quoted premiums so high that they cannot afford to pay. This creaming is destroying the community spirit of this country.

It has been put to me that the remaining public liability insurersâpost the HIH collapseâmeet to divide the market and agree on premiums. There seems to be too great a similarity between insurance companies as to the areas that get coverage and those that do not. This collusion must be investigated and stopped immediately. Is it true that underwriters are warning companies to stay away from the United States, Canada and New South Wales, in particular in this country, because of the litigious nature of these jurisdictions? This is a warning to us all that something has to change. Litigation and large payouts are reducing or eliminating the insurance cover available in some jurisdictions.

Tasmania is also behind the eight ball in that it is affected by insurance companies making decisions in Melbourne or Sydney without knowledge of Tasmanian organisations or the environment in which they operate. I would like to quote from an article in today's Mercury entitled `Liability, the horse that bolted', which states the example of Luiz Menezes of Kingston, in my electorate, who runs a commercial riding school. He has public liability insurance which five years ago through TGIO cost him $250. The article states:

quote.para: When TGIO withdrew, he had to switch to a mainland broker and the following year his premium rose to $3000. Now he pays $7000 a year.

speech.para: He had recently received an invitation to `reinsure through Lloyds of London when his insurance expires in December'. The article continues:

quote.para: But the premium was to be $14,000. He said getting public liability insurance was becoming extremely difficult.
âA lot of people will not get an invitation to reinsure,â Mr Menezes said.
He believed public liability insurance would be unavailable in Australia soon, forcing people to look overseas.
âWhat do you do, fly by the seat of your pants [uninsured], or pay the huge premiums?â Mr Menezes said.
âI haven't a clue which way to go.
âIt's taken me 27 years to set my business up.
âI have been a coach for 35 yearsâwhat am I going to do?â

speech.para: I was also appalled to hear that the Police and Citizens Youth Club on Bruny Island has ceased operations. Other PCYCs have ceased their martial arts and football programs, reverting to eight ball and other benign activities. The fabric of the good that these clubs are doing is being torn apart. We stand to transfer our youth from these activities to less acceptable activities if we do not fix this problem. It gives me great pleasure to support this motion and to repeat my call for an urgent inquiry into insurance company collusion in the setting of premiums and the allocation of market share.

talk.start.para: âI applaud the member for Corangamite for his motion today because this issue is of grave concern to all of us, as we have all heard. The related issues are that volunteer and small, not-for-profit groups cannot pay premiums; small business in all its forms cannot pay premiums; providers of essential services in areas such as the health sector cannot pay the premiums; and local government, the deliverer of many services, cannot pay premiums. But in all cases the brunt of this problem is probably being borne most significantly in country areas. Although the metropolitan areas are affected admittedly to a degree, this is a classic country problem because of where we are and the way in which our various community structures operate, in that they are generally volunteer organisations and small businesses. Many organisations in many of our electorates have closed their doors and many more are threatening to close.

speech.para: This issue threatens the social fabric of country Australia. We have the problem for a variety of reasons, some of which are known and have been espoused: the HIH collapse, September 11 in 2001 and reinsurance cost increases. However, the real reason that has become obvious is that Australians are no longer taking responsibility for their own actions. The member for Gilmore referred to this problem during her speech this afternoon. It also encompasses increasing litigation, law firms advertising and touting for business, a widening interpretation of the principles of negligence, erosion of the concept of personal accountability, and growth in the culture of blame. These are all reasons for the problems that we are currently experiencing. There are various prospective solutions, all to be found around the following principles: that it is a state issue, that the Commonwealth has a limited role in the sense of acting as catalyst to bring the states together, and that the Commonwealth can also prospectively assist through the activities of APRA and the ACCC. In essence, though, the answers appear to all be at state level. Ideally we would have all state jurisdictions adopt a series of principles which would provide the basis of a common approach across all jurisdictions.

In the National Party working group that worked on public liability earlier this year, we identified specific legislative options that the states and territories could now introduce, all of which should apply to claims for personal injuries. Firstly, there would be an exemption from liability for the acts of volunteers and smaller community organisations. I am pleased to see that some of the states are already considering those processes. Next would be the introduction of a threshold, the introduction of a cap and the use of structured settlements to incorporate lump-sum payments and annuity benefits. Various measures to reduce the awards of damages would include the introduction of a discount rate that would be applicable to claims for future loss, the abolition of interest on damages, and a deduction from damages awards reflecting non-refundable gains such as personal insurance policies, superannuation benefits and the like to thereby avoid double-dipping.

The abolition of no-win, no-pay advertising by legal practitioners is an essential to proceed with. Currently we have law firms touting for business through hospital emergency sectionsâand what has anyone got to lose? The ethos of Australians making their own way has been replaced by Australians needing to make a fast buck whether or not they deserve to make a fast buck. Nobody is trying to eliminate the possibility of those people with real, long-term damages being able to access benefits. However, many of the people who get benefits are certainly not really entitled to them. As I said, we would like to see a deduction from damages awards reflecting non-refundable gains, to avoid that double-dipping.

Again, the abolition of advertising needs to be entrenched in law in order for us to prevent such things as no-win, no-pay arrangements. We need improvements in pre-trial processes to maximise opportunities for settlements, with these to include exchange of expert reports, exchange of summaries of evidence to be called from experts and a compulsory mediation process. All in all, there is much work to be done to ensure that the social fabric of Australian society continues with volunteer organisations being able to deliver much needed services. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â In talking today about public liability insurance and the crisis in this area, I first want to say that there are a number of community groups and volunteer organisations in my electorate that are suffering very seriously from the increases in premiums that all of the honourable members have spoken about. The Daily Telegraph had a series called `The death of fun' that covered some of the sporting events, the community events, the fetes and so on that have been cancelled because of premium increases. There is no simple resolution to this problem, and I think that it is dishonest to pretend that there is. But there are some things that we can and must do as a nation. We must ensure, first of all, that the Commonwealth takes some responsibility for the crisis in this area and works cooperatively with the states instead of the duckshoving that has been going on up till now. In relation to this area, the Commonwealth reminds me a little bit of Bart Simpson when he says, `I didn't do it. I wasn't there and you can't prove I was anyway.'

speech.para: The Commonwealth needs to have a look at the proposals made by the states at last week's national summit on public liability insurance. Some of the tort law reform that is going on in the states must be supported, and consideration should be given to the development of a national uniform approach in that area. We also have to think about taking away the right of people who are engaged in criminal activity being able to sue if they are injured during the course of that criminal activity. It seems like commonsense, really, doesn't it? We need to ensure that the courts begin to take account of the influence of excessive drug and alcohol use on people who then go on to do stupid things and are injured in the course of doing those things.

I am pleased that the ACCC is going to be monitoring the insurance industry. When we are talking about the sorts of measures I am proposing, we must ensure that they are not just one more way of the insurance companies making super profits. It is already obvious that the business of insurance companies is picking up, and it will continue to pick up. Even if we do make the changes that are being proposed by the states, we need to ensure that those changes are actually passed on in reduced premiums and not just held on to by the insurance companies.

On the other hand, however, the system cannot work effectively if the trend that we seem to be pursuing now continues. Not long ago in Australia we used to laugh at examples from America where people were suedâfor example, where a doctor may have been sued because he or she stopped to give aid at a car accident that he or she drove past. We thought it was ridiculous that, if someone walked on your front lawn and tripped over your hose, they could sue you. What seems to be happening in Australia now is that there is an increase in the litigiousness of our community, and these sorts of examples certainly do not seem as far-fetched as they once did.

I heard an example last week of a fellow who had been sitting in the backseat of a taxi. He was very, very drunk and climbed out of the window of the taxi and was surfing on the roof of the taxi. The taxi driver turned around, saw that no-one was in the cab and stopped suddenly, wondering what happened to his passenger. The passenger fell off the roof, landed in front of the taxi and was quite seriously injured. This was settled out of court. This did not even go to court, because the taxi company did not think that they could win a case against this claim for negligence. I think we have come to an absurd situation in this country. There is also the example of the man who, after a night of drinking and taking ecstasy, dived into a sandbank at Bondi. Now Waverley Council is wondering whether it can afford to provide lifesaving on its beaches. They cannot prevent idiots who have been out drinking all night doing stupid things at the beach. I do not think anyone could claim that any level of government could protect itself from those sorts of claims if that is what we come to.

I also think the size of some of these claims by people who have acted foolishly under the influence of drugs or alcohol are a real insult to the victims of crime who are able to receive a maximum of $50,000. I think it is an affront that we have these inequities in the system, especially when one takes into account the difference between someone who is sexually assaulted and the impact on her life forever and someone who has fallen off the roof of a taxi because they are too drunk to behave sensibly. We need the Commonwealth to take a leadership role that ensures that genuine victims are not disadvantaged but that brakes are put on greedy insurance companies and unscrupulous ambulance-chasing lawyers, like the ones from the Australian Plaintiff Lawyers Association who appear in today's Herald, using injured people to push their case with the state government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI commend the member for Corangamite on his motion with regard to public liability insurance, but I use this opportunity to add a further dimension to the debate on insurance generally in the country. I listened with interest to the previous speaker, the member for Sydney. She drew attention to the stupid actions which surely need reviewing in terms of payouts. But the fact remains that, at some point, the costs involved with such stupid actions have to be picked up somewhere along the line by either insurance payouts or the taxpayer.

speech.para: I am today submitting a motion to the Clerk. I have drafted this motion in some detail with the help of the parliamentary advisory system. The motion is seconded by the member for Kennedy and is supported by my Independent colleague from New England. It calls on the Commonwealth to use the power available to it under the Constitution with regard to insurance and to order an inquiry by the Australian Law Reform Commission into the best way to handle this situation. The current ad hoc approach to the crisis cannot continue. As the Prime Minister has said, the taxpayer cannot be expected to write a blank cheque for insurance, be it for doctors or public liability. But, from what I have seen so far, the measures that have been suggested may stem the flow but, in large degree, appear to be bandaid measures only.

In this motion I am proposing that the parliament ask the government to request the Australian Law Reform Commission to examine the viability of a national claims act, providing a uniform national insurance claims standard with clear and particular reference to the viability of lump sum payment caps, specific criteria to assess disability, standardised damages claims under all types of insurance, the regulation of medical defence organisations as insurance companies, and changes in insurance claims from lump sum payments to income streams, annuities or structured settlements.

The Australian Law Commission, directed by the Commonwealth, should be the first step in providing a concrete solution to the crisis situation that we currently face. I commend this notice of motion to honourable members for serious examination, receiving as I have today, an email from the Burraga sheep show and Oberon horse trial organisers to say that these events look like hitting the wallâand the Oberon horse trials have produced gold medal performances at the last three Olympics.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 1.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for Calare will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

âI would like today to congratulate the Lions Club of CanberraâKambah on the event of their 25th anniversary. I had the pleasure of attending their 25th anniversary dinner on Saturday just gone. This club was chartered on 30 April 1977 with 24 original charter members. They then came from the developing suburbs of Kambah and Wanniassa in the Tuggeranong Valley, an area which today houses over 90,000 people. In that first year the club raised $5,760 and donated to charities including the Kambah Scouts, the Lions Save-Sight Foundation and the New South Wales Muscular Dystrophy Association. They even donated blankets for distribution to needy families in the valley.

speech.para: The club's view of life is that for most of its members and their families the Kambah Lions Club is not just a club. It goes beyond thatâthe bonds of friendship are very strong. They continue to exist and the members today are doing as their past members did: raising moneys for the community in which they live.

In fact they have also produced a 25-year history of their club, and Rhoda Parker needs to be congratulated for that wonderful edition that she has put together. I am enjoying reading it because there is much local history in it outside and beyond the Lions Club. I just want to take the opportunity to congratulate all past and present members of the Lions Club at Kambah and say good on them. And to all clubs similar to theirs, all success for the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â The Bracks government happily takes and spends federal money while arrogantly disregarding its obligations to properly outline when it intends to complete the Scoresby Freeway. Federal funding for the Scoresby Freeway is the largest single expenditure item in the 2002-03 federal roads budgetâ the cash is already flowing. We know the project will deliver major economic benefits and support much of the work to attract investment and employment opportunities and improve living standards for the community that I represent.

speech.para: Honourable members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe state government cannot even tell us when the southern section of the freeway connecting the Frankston Freeway to the Monash Freeway is to be completed. The section produces the greatest benefits to the community and outperforms all other sections of the freeway, andâincluding my hecklers here on my side of the Houseâwe cannot even find out when that is due to be completed. While the state Labor government continues to behave as reluctant converts to be Integrated Scoresby Transport Corridor Project, I am hopeful that the Victorian government will take its responsibilities seriously and let our community know when this important section of the freeway will be completed.

speech.para: I might also add it is nonsense to claim, as the Bracks government does, that the much needed on-ramp at Rutherford Road to connect the industrial and commercial areas north of Frankston to the Frankston Freeway is being delayed because of the Scoresby Freeway project. It is nonsense to suggest they are connected. They are stand-alone projects, both deserving of support. We need to get that on-ramp in place and available to take full benefit of what will flow from the Scoresby transport corridor project. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI object to the trial by media to which the Catholic Archbishop of Sydney, Dr George Pell, is being subjected concerning paedophilia in the church. No mention has been made of the fact that when Dr Pell was appointed Archbishop of Melbourne he appointed an independent commission to investigate allegations of sexual abuse in the diocese. He created a compensation panel and he set up a counselling and support service for victims of sexual abuse.

speech.para: It is a national scandal that people placed in a position of trust of young people betray this trust in the form of sexual abuse. Society, as well as churches, must continue to work to stamp out this disease in our society. People who are paedophiles must be subject to the full force of civil law. But, more importantly, victims of paedophilia must be granted every assistance to recover from their horrendous experience.

talk.start.para: âI would like to take this opportunity to commend the heroic actions of one of my constituents Mr Joe Amodeo from my electorate of Makin. On Thursday, 30 May 2002 a Cessna 150 Aerobat aircraft crash landed into a light pole at the front of Joe's home in Pooraka. The aircraft had been stolen from Parafield Gardens airport.

speech.para: Although Joe did not expect to find any survivors, he rushed over to the aircraft and immobilised it by switching off the electronics and turning off the fuel. According to a newspaper report in the Adelaide Advertiser, Joe, a recreational pilot for more than 25 years, dragged the pilot from the crashed aircraft onto grass about 30 metres from the scene:

quote.para: He [the pilot] was drifting in and out of consciousness,' he said. `I just kept talking to him and asking him what had happened. He said he was learning to fly and he took it for a joy ride.' Mr Amodeo and a neighbour then covered the pilot, who was soaked in petrol, with a jacket and waited for paramedics to arrive at the scene.

speech.para: What Joe and his neighbours in Pooraka did was an unselfish and heroic act for the safety of the community without thinking of their own safety. I am very proud of them and commend them on their actions for the safety of our community.

talk.start.para: âThe other day as I drove along Cabramatta Road, Cabramatta, past the Free Serbian Orthodox church, I noticed a funeral was taking place. The flower draped hearse and mourning cars were surrounded by family and friends attending the funeral of a loved one. What also caught my eye was a bus stop advertisement directly outside the church. The ad showed the exposed outstretched leg of a woman with a caption `die smiling'. The ad was deliberately suggestive and, I would think, any reasonable person would consider it inappropriate in that location.

speech.para: Further along Cabramatta Road I came to the Chinese Buddhist temple, a place where the ashes of deceased members of the community are interred. A similar bus stop ad showed a buxom young woman in a lace braâagain, I would think an inappropriate location for such an ad. It struck me that, had these advertisements been placed outside St Andrews Cathedral in Sydney last Friday, there would have been an immediate outcry. But it seems that advertisers are not as sensitive when it comes to the sacred sites and places of worship of people from other cultures.

talk.start.para: âI rise to express my concern about last night's 60 Minutes program entitled `Loss of faith'. The program referred to child sex abuse and the inference that the Archbishop of Sydney, George Pell, was involved in a cover-up. As MPs, we are justly criticised if we abuse the forms of the House to lay down unsubstantiated allegations. The use of the media to air allegations without sound evidence is equally offensive to those who believe that the essence of our democratic freedoms must be protected, in contrast to perpetuating the growing number of cases of trial by media insinuation or speculation.

speech.para: There is a propensity in the media these days to allow it to be used by individuals or fringe groups looking to smear public figures. Often this is done under the guise of newsworthiness, public interest or being a messenger of the news. Whatever the reason, all of us who can command the airwaves have a common public responsibility for truth and justice. The use of innuendo through selective questioning, editing and production can be designed to discredit individuals or at least cast doubt on their credibility.

This morning Archbishop Pell laid out the events and his account of what took place. I look forward to the media's frenzy being tempered with an eye on judicial fair playâ not for the sake of the archbishop alone, nor the Catholic Church, but, importantly, for the sake of the victims and their families, who have had to suffer and deal with the effects of such abuse for many years. The allegations and subsequent charges against the perpetrators of these heinous crimes are indeed serious, and those guilty deserve the full weight of the law to come down upon them. Yet that is a matter for our legal system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn the weekend I had the opportunity to attend the 90th anniversary celebrations of the Jewish cultural centre, Kadimah. Kadimah was formed in 1911, first in Bourke Street, just down the road from the Victorian parliament. Its founders were predominantly recently arrived immigrants from Poland, Eastern Europe and Russia. English and Hebrew were initially the preferred languages of the majority of members and Yiddish was looked down on by some of the members of the organisation at that time. Ten years later, in 1921, one of the major international figures of the Yiddish literary renaissance, Perets Hirshbayn, arrived in Australia. It will surprise the Speaker and this parliament to know that he was greeted like a movie star. This proved to be the harbinger of things to come for that organisation. They had many other very famous people arrive throughout the decades, including the poet Melekh Ravich and the pedagogue Yosef Giligich. The first Yiddish book was published by this organisation in Australia. It was Der Oystralisher Almanach, the Australian Almanac. The Kadimah also organised the first commemoration of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising on 19 April 1945 at war's end.

speech.para: The organisation expanded dramatically in the postwar period when many new Australians came. They were called `Der Grine' by the existing members of the Kadimah. Arthur Calwell, the then minister for immigration, was said to have told Mr Leo Fink, one of the benefactors of the organisation, that members of the organisation had a lot of cousins in Poland. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â The participation rate of women in the work force is at one of its highest levels, and to maintain this level in the current strong economic climate we need to develop workplace practices that encourage women's participation in the work force while creating no penalty against them for their decision to manage both family and a career. Job sharing provides opportunities for working mothers to coordinate their career and family time. It also provides an opportunity to increase the participation of more mature part-time workers in the work force. Not only would there be an exchange of skills between the two, there could also be an exchange of life knowledge. It would help to reposition mature age employees in the work force and provide for growth in the labour market area.

speech.para: Job sharing is not about solving the paid maternity leave issue but about finding measures that enable women to combine work and family and about enhancing the skill base of Australia. It is a win-win situation. It encourages opportunity for a range of workers rather than for a subset. Workplace policy needs to accommodate changes in our work force culture. There is also need to increase our birthrate, while the average age of our population means that more mature age people will remain in the work force for much longer. Rather than advocating paid maternity leave as the standard, we need to consider making changes that will benefit all players in the workplace environment.

talk.start.para: âToday marks the 10th anniversary of the High Court's landmark Mabo decision, which recognised the native title rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and overturned the idea of terra nullius.
