talk.start.para: âI too welcome and fully endorse the motion put forward by the member for Curtin, which draws attention to the need for additional funding for the National Health and Medical Research Council, to be allocated specifically in this case for research into the various forms of muscular dystrophy. In doing so, it is in fact a bit difficultâdifficult in a constructive sense, I would like to thinkâbecause, when calling for additional funds for muscular dystrophy, it is hard to forget cystic fibrosis, asthma, cancer, childhood arthritis and a range of other disorders and diseases, all of which I am sure we could stand up for here today and fully support a call for additional funding. I do not mean that in any sense to denigrate this call so much as to remind all of us of the areas desperately needing dollars to go into the area of research.

speech.para: I will just digress very slightly for a moment. In Backing Australia's Abilityâthe government's research policy paper tabled last yearâthe government wanted to set priorities. They included a range of priorities which I think we would all applaud. I would like to think that, if the government were serious about funding not only muscular dystrophy but also a range of other medical research requiring suitable funding, if the government applied the criteria that is in that paper, they would find themselves able, at least in principle, to come along and support entirely any call for an increase in funding that would be required for research into muscular dystrophy, any of the other diseases that I have mentioned and the numerous others that exist.

But I will come back to the motion moved by the member for Curtin. I believe that the United States, along with some other overseas countries, actually contributes more to research into muscular dystrophy in Australia than is currently provided by the government. That is not me knocking the government so much as putting into perspective where the funding is coming from and where we believe we should be upping the ante, to coin a phrase. In 2001 the NHMRC had something like $335,000 that could have been used for this purpose. Between 1999 and 2003 the Australian Research Council had $470,000. There is a list of state governments and private or non-government fundraising efforts over the years. Red Rooster is a famous one. I think over a period of 18 years they have raised something like $1 millionâall for muscular dystrophy research.

Medical research has a proud record in this country. Genome mapping and stem cell research I think are going to offer more help yet. But the research needs to be targeted, and I am sure I am not the only person in this place who has received letters from parents in the last few months particularly urging us all to support stem cell research for the reason that they can see a potential that could help and widen the opportunities for research and for success in muscular dystrophy as in a range of other disorders.

As other speakers have already mentioned, muscular dystrophy is an appalling thing that you would not wish on anyone. Duchenne is the worst and the most prevalent. The symptoms sometimes in their early stages would not necessarily be linked to muscular dystrophy. It could be cardiac problems, cataracts, testicular atrophy, respiratory and gastrointestinal disorders, a slight form of mental retardation, scoliosis or muscle wastingâthere is a range of indications that can lead to muscular dystrophy.

It is fair also to mention, as the member for Curtin has pointed out, the inheritance of this disease. I understand that if one parent has the disease, even if only mildly, there is probably a fifty-fifty chance that it can be transferred on. I would like to urge all members of this place to support this motion and, in doing so, continue to urge the government of the day to think more carefully about how they can spend their science dollar and look very carefully at medical research, particularly in those disorders that affect our children and therefore affect many lives rippling out from that child. Muscular dystrophy, and the Duchenne version of it, is a terrible thing and we would not want to see anyone suffer from it. I fully endorse this motion and urge all efforts that we can raise into getting more money into the medical research end of this particular disorder.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption for this debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âThe grievance debate this afternoon gives me the opportunity to comment on a recent announcement by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services on the AusLink plan and the absolute hypocrisy displayed by the minister on this issue. Just one week after the release of the Treasurer's budget, where it was revealed $300 million is to be cut from federal budget funding over the next two years, we have seen an astonishing backflip by the minister for transport on his plans for the future of land transport infrastructure development. Yet he refuses to see anything in transport beyond its relevance to the farm gate. He is irresponsibly inept and blinkered on the challenges of urban congestion.

speech.para: The minister claims that this is a new approach by the government to do what he describes as make the `hard decisions' that are needed in Australia's national interest. Whilst this is a new approach by the minister, it is certainly not an original new approach. Ever since I assumed responsibility for the infrastructure portfolio this has been firmly on the Labor Party's agenda. I have consistently called for a smarter approach to infrastructure planning and management and an integrated national transport plan to secure the economic and social growth of Australia. The record will show that Labor took to the last election a plan for the establishment of a national infrastructure advisory council. That plan would see the private sector and all tiers of government working together to tackle infrastructure policy blockages. The policy also argued for an integrated approach to transport challenges and a national land transport plan. When this important policy initiative was announced, what was the minister's response? Did he support it? Most definitely not.

The minister, as the Hansard record shows, mocked Labor's plan and has continued to do so. In this place on 3 April last year the minister had the gall to claim this policy took a `top down' approach to regional and rural infrastructure. Clearly, the minister's attempt at the old smoke and mirrors trick is fatally flawed. Our policy unequivocally stressed a cooperative approach to infrastructure planning by all tiers of government and private enterprise. The minister's plan proposes no such thing. Instead of working with the states, local councils and private enterprise, the minister for transport wants them working for him. His plan constantly stresses that the Commonwealth government will be the decision maker. But all the time the plan puts the onus on the states, local governments and private partners to actually develop good infrastructure policy.

The proposal paves the way for the Commonwealth to make funding decisions based purely on local political considerations. It is about drawing state, local and Commonwealth funds under the federal minister's discretion. The minister has also hankered to claw back GST funding from the states. Yet again, the GST deal is revealed as ill-considered and regretted by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

The AusLink planâor can I say the `Ausdud' plan, as it has been renamed by one of my Labor colleagues at a state levelâis without a doubt a blatant attempt at breaking down the national highway system and shirking the federal government's responsibility for that national highway system. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, as you know from the importance of the highway upgrade in your own electorate, national highways are the arteries of Australia. They are the vital transport link across the nation and the national highway system, by its very nature, is, and should be, a Commonwealth responsibility. In the same manner, the states and local government have clear responsibilities. It should not be open to the Commonwealth to arbitrarily tip bits of money towards state and local roads with no reference to broader plans and priorities for those authorities.

It is also unrealistic to expect a broader program to be delivered within existing funds. Where is the funding for the planâa blatant black hole in the minister's announcement? The minister's speech to the Re-engineering Australia Forum a fortnight ago made just one mention of the federal government's commitment to funding the planâthat is, to amalgamate Commonwealth land transport funding. There is no top-up, no additional funding for growing responsibilities to overcome the backlog on the infrastructure front. In essence, this can only mean one thing: less money into our national highway system. That is exceptionally important, because all around Australia we have major challenges to actually upgrade the national highway system, especially with respect to some of the major accidents that have occurred in recent times. In other words, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is yet again going to rob Peter to pay Paul. What he proposes is that the Commonwealth scrap existing funding allocations, toss all the money into one pot controlled by the Commonwealth government and therefore put in jeopardy a number of essential transport infrastructure projects.

The minister also claimed that the federal government has committed every cent it had promised in the lead-up to last year's election. Let us recall what occurred. We had the minister flouncing about the countryside in a VIP jet, paid for by taxpayers, throwing money here and money there, promising everything if it delivered a vote, especially to National Party members in a range of marginal seats in northern New South Wales and Queensland. It is interesting to note that around the corridors some Liberal members of the coalition have actually pointed to the fact that they received very little from those announcements and that in essence it was a National Party program for members of the National Party caucus only.

But now we have seen that $300 million had to be taken from committed roadworks to pay for those priorities. It is now blatantly clear that the minister could not afford his road commitments or his Black Spot program without taking it from other projects. The projects most at risk under the minister's AusLink are the politically unpopular projects, regardless of their safety priority. The gross deception of the electorate is that he was not honest about the cost of his commitments. He did not tell those whose projects have been cut, and the workers who will lose jobs as a result, that the promises had a big price tag. How, then, can the minister credibly commit to this announcement? Not only have we seen $300 million cut from roads funding in the budget, but the hollow commitment that the money is there in later years, indeed out years, is a disgraceful attempt by the minister to cover his own inadequacies. He has other plans for those out years, when he will have his new slush fund approach ready for the next election. AusLink has emerged from the minister only as a strategy to get him out of a funding fix. What kind of accountability is that?

There is no longer a firm commitment to fund any promised projects on the National Highway, Roads of National Importance and Roads to Recovery. Where was the minister's commitment to an integrated, inter-modal land transport plan in his election policy, in his statement of his third-term agenda or the budget? It was absent, missing, not thought of by the minister because it required a little bit of hard workâsomething that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is not well known for.

If there is one thing that is certain, it is that Australia is facing serious transport challenges over the coming years. We need an integrated, intermodal approach to transport infrastructure to ensure that Australia has a modern, efficient and effective transport system. We need efficient passenger and freight transport networks linking Australian communities and Australia to the world and we need a progressive transport policy that addresses the challenges it faces. But it hinges around government accepting responsibility. We also need a minister that is genuinely committed to those changes, not committed to using those challenges to cover his political hide. AusLink is nothing short of a cheap attempt at cost shifting and responsibility shifting in an effort by an inept minister to hide his own shortcomings.
Labor has long recognised the need for a change in thinking on national transport infrastructure. We will deliver. (Time expired)

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
Mr ENTSCH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âI rise today to share with the House the story of a remarkable little boy in my electorate of Leichhardt. His struggle and his triumph are directly tied to a political decision that this government will soon have to make. The wrong decision could prove extremely detrimental to Sam Endres and hundreds of others in a similar situation. Sam Endres was born profoundly deaf but, because he is such an intelligent child, his parents Paul and Kerrie did not know that something was wrong until Sam was some two years old. Paul Endres told me in a recent meeting I had with him that the days following Sam's prognosis were the bleakest in his and his wife's lives, because the prospects for Sam's educational years were poor at best and absolutely debilitating at worst.

speech.para: Sam's parents were reportedly told by medical and educational experts that the best they could hope for was that he would communicate by sign language and that he would not progress past a year 4 reading level. Sam has a physical shortcoming but he is in no way mentally disabled, yet Queensland Education told the Endres family that in Cairns the only way Sam could be schooled was through a special school predominantly catering for children with mental and severe learning disabilities, not physical disabilities. To place Sam, an intelligent child by anyone's standards, in this environment would literally cripple his own learning abilities, locking him out of the opportunities that other children with his mental capacity take for granted. Paul and Kerrie were quite understandably devastated.

But for Sam there came hope, and that hope was a cochlear implant. Just before he turned three, Sam received the gift of hearing through a cochlear implant. I have a photograph of Sam at the exact moment that he heard his first ever sound. His expression certainly shows the miracle of his new ability. I would like to table this photograph. Sam is now five years of age and is currently completing his first year of school in a mainstream school, not a special school. What is more, he is the best reader in his class, thanks to his cochlear implant and the accompanying auditory-verbal therapy that enables Sam's brain to interpret sound.

Professor Graeme Clark invented the cochlear implant and he specifically built it in two separate devicesâthe internal implant itself, which comprises a series of electrodes threaded through the cochlear, and the speech processing unit. Everyday sounds are picked up through the microphone attached to the speech processor and processed by the computer in the processor. The processor then sends these sounds to the implant embedded in the cochlear in the form of electronic signals that the brain can then interpret. Speech processors used to be very heavy and cumbersome and were carried about in a backpack but, as technology has progressed, the speech processors have become very small; the latest version fits snugly around the ear.

It is precisely because of the technology that is constantly improving that Professor Clark made the deliberate decision to separate the cochlear implant into two distinct parts. The beauty of it is that the recipient does not require invasive surgery every time the unit is upgraded, only the first time when the implant is inserted. The part that is upgraded is the processor and it requires no surgery and therefore no risk. Every upgrade and every technological advancement maximises a recipient's hearing capability. It is vital that children especially receive the latest upgrades as soon as they are available. Once a recipient receives a cochlear implant, of course they must learn to use it, which involves a long and intensive period of teaching the brain how to interpret the signals created by the implant. The younger the recipient, the easier it is for them to learn to use the implant in the most effective way, and the easier it is to teach them speech.

Because Sam was a very young recipient, his speech is perfect. It is much harder for a person who has been deaf for many years to achieve that clear speech. Until a child is six, his or her brain has what doctors call `elasticity'âan incredible capacity to absorb new things, almost like a sponge. This is the key reason that hearing specialists like to implant cochlear units in recipients as young as 12 months of age. It is extremely important to the child recipient because they can learn and become educated unhindered by physical barriers. Obviously, if a child like Sam can hear, speak and be understood before he reaches school age, he will not lose out on critical educational time, which leads me to why I have raised Sam's story in this House.

Last year, the Private Health Industry Medical Devices Expert Committee recommended that requirements for health funds to provide upgraded and/or replacement speech processors for cochlear implants be removed, the reason being that private funds should not have to cover procedures that do not involve surgery. Of course, we all know that if a health fund is no longer obliged to provide free speech processors to their customers, in all likelihood they will not. This will mean that parents, despite contributing to a private health fund, will have to pay for processors themselves at a cost of between $8,000 and $10,000âa price that most cannot afford.

If this recommendation is accepted, the only alternative available for these families, other than scraping together some $10,000, will be to apply for a processor through the Australian Hearing Service. That means sitting on a waiting list, possibly for months. I suggest that families did not join expensive private health funds to be put on a waiting list. Unfortunately, due to accidental breakages, malfunctions and technological advancements, a child will need several speech processors in their youth. Every day that Sam wears his processor in early childhood is absolutely critical to his future ability to hear, speak and learn. Children with cochlear implants require the latest, most current technology to maximise their speech capability. I believe that to deny them this capability is unacceptable and discriminatory. These kids cannot afford to be left with no hearing ability for those weeks or months between losing the use of their existing speech processor and reaching the head of the AHS queue. Every day a child lives without a speech processor severely hampers their progress in communicating with the rest of the world. Going without a speech processor for a month, or even a week, will halt their progress completely. And if that child is in school, they may never be able to catch up on the lessons that they missed while they were deaf to the world.

I understand that advice from the Department of Health and Ageing is that some $1.6 million has been committed over four years for AHS to fund replacement speech processors. The department advises that it is confident that this represents sufficient funding. But I have had other advice suggesting that this amount falls grossly short of the actual amount of funds that would be required if patients suddenly lose their private health coverage. I am concerned that the new pressure on the AHS will make a tough situation much worse, exacerbating the already long waiting list. This is simply unacceptable. When the committee reviewed the speech processor, I believe it made a terrible mistake. It grouped the speech processor in with hundreds of prosthetics it was also reviewing. Speech processors are not like artificial limbs and should not be reviewed as such. I firmly believe that the unique technology of the cochlear implant is so different that it is beyond the intent of the current legislation. The implant is one item comprising two parts. They cannot be independent pieces of equipment: one half will not work without the other and it must be treated as one item. The speech processor should never under any circumstances have been classed as a prosthesis.

As Paul and Kerrie's elected member of parliamentâand as Sam's elected member of parliamentâI implore this government not to accept the recommendation of the committee to remove the requirement of health funds to provide speech processor upgrades and replacements. Give the speech processor the special consideration it deserves and examine cochlear implants as a completely separate issue. We cannot deny these children the rights of hearing and speech that we all take for granted. We cannot jeopardise their capabilities and their futures. I want to see Sam Endres grow up, go to university, and make his special mark in life. I do not want to see Sam Endresâand so many other young people like himâstruggle all his life with a reading level of grade 4 or less when it is totally avoidable and very much in our hands. I hope that every honourable member in this place feels the same as I do.

talk.start.para: (Mr Hawker)âOrder! During his speech, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources sought leave to table a document. Is leave granted?

interjection.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â On 17 September 1987, I stood in this place to give my first speech to the parliament. In the course of that speech, I made a number of comments which related to my commitment to ensuring the recognition of Aboriginal rights to land. Indeed, today we are celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Mabo decision. It is something which I know many Australians applaud, although someânotably the oppositionâfailed to at the time and certainly have remained in a position of opposition. During that first speech to the federal parliament, I made a number of points. Remember that this was the year prior to the bicentenary. On the matter to do with Aboriginal interests in land, I said:

quote.para: This is one issue which I believe to be of pre-eminent importance as we approach 1988. As a nation we have yet to recognise and accord Aboriginal people the justice that is their due.

speech.para: I then quoted from an address by a now deceased significant Australian author, Xavier Herbert, who, on addressing the issue of Aboriginal land rights, said:

quote.para: Until we give back to the black man just a bit of the land that was his, without strings to snatch it back, without anything but complete generosity of spirit in concession for the evil we have done himâuntil we do that, we will remain what we have always been so far, a people without integrity; not a nation but a community of thieves.

speech.para: That speech was made 11 years after the passage of the Northern Territory land rights legislation, but it was not until the High Court brought down the Mabo No. 2 decision in June 1992 that it became evidentâas a result of the actions by Eddie Mabo in taking the Mer people's case to the High Courtâthat Aboriginal rights to land, in terms of expunging the doctrine of terra nullius, were recognised.

After the 1993 election, the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, decided that something needed to be done to convert the decision of the High Court into law. As a result of that, I was privileged, along with my colleague sitting at the table, the member for Banks, to be involved integrally in the development of the initial native title legislation. Indeed, the Aboriginal negotiating team, which was primarily responsible for negotiating the arrangement not only for the Native Title Act but for a package of three thingsâa social justice package, an indigenous land fund and the Native Title Actâoften worked in a room adjacent to my office. I know the member for Banks has some significant and important records of some of those meetings, none of which he released to the press, of course.

Importantly, at the time the opposition railed against it and saw it as the end of life as we all knew it in Australia. Subsequently, I vividly recall sitting in front of the television and seeing maps of Australia and the current Prime Minister sayingâthis was prior to the 1998 amendments to the Native Title Actâ`Aboriginal people are going to claim your backyard.' Of course, that was never going to be the case. Those with any knowledge of the High Court decision knew it to be the case. Informed people in the then oppositionânow the governmentâshould have known it to be the case, but the fact is they chose to ignore what was patently obvious to anyone who had any understanding at all of what the High Court had determined.

Then, of course, the Keating government was defeated and, in 1998, amendments to the legislation were put before the parliament. The amendments sought to amend the rights to claim and negotiate and, sadly, to extinguish native title. On the positive side, they did provide a legislative basis for regional agreements, upon which many negotiations have taken place subsequently. But I recall that, at the time, the amendments followed the High Court's decision on Wik, which in 1996 found that native title could coexist with pastoral leases on their landâ the issue of coexistence of title.

I was at the High Court on that particular dayâan historic occasionâas was the member for Banks. There was a gallery of interested Indigenous participants, as well as a phalange of legal representatives that you would have needed the Treasury to look after. The court made its determination and, within hours, the then Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, Tim Fischer, attacked the integrity of the High Court and said that, effectively, they were doing this nation a disservice, an injusticeâ much in the same way as the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is doing about the judges of the Federal Court. This tells me a lot about where the government is coming from in relation to these debates.

Then we had that extensive negotiation leading up to the 1998 amendments which were carried on the back of the Wik determination by the High Court. At that point I was working for the National Indigenous Working Group, being engaged in the negotiations to get an outcome in this place. Of course, Indigenous people were to be disappointed, because significant changes were made to the act which had a detrimental effect on their rights. When I came into parliament, I pledged to represent the interests of Aboriginal Australians, who comprised a significant proportion of my then electorate, the Northern Territory. I now represent the seat of Lingiari. About 40 per cent of my constituents are Aboriginal Australians.

It is important that we understand that we still have work to do to ensure that Aboriginal AustraliansâIndigenous Australiansâ get the justice that is their due. We ought to understand that the Native Title Act, far from providing the capacity for Indigenous Australians to claim people's backyards, has become, as a direct result of the 1998 amendments, very restrictive in terms of providing the capacity for Indigenous people to make claims over land which they regard traditionally as theirs. It seems that Indigenous Australians, particularly those who have no direct contact with their country, have tragically been missed out. Nothing has yet been done by any government subsequent to the 1993 native title legislation to put in place the social justice package which in part was designed to ameliorate the difference between people who could have access to native title and people who would be denied access to native title. The social justice package would have addressed the issues of employment, health, education and access to property that many Indigenous Australians still believe they have been excluded from.

On many occasions I am recorded as reminding people about the importance of Aboriginal land. I remain committed, as I have been since my first speech in 1987, to ensuring that, where we can, we obtain the justice that is due to Indigenous Australians. I remain committed to that agenda. We need to take every opportunity to ensure that we get it right. We can put it right by being considerate and understanding and by sitting down to negotiate adequate and appropriate outcomes with Indigenous Australians who continue to demand that their rights be recognised.

talk.start.para: âI rise to raise the matter of the World Wide Fund for Nature and their continuing campaign against the sugarcane farming industry in Queensland. The WWF have engaged in a concerted campaign against the sugar industry in Queensland since mid-2001, alleging that it is causing damage to the Great Barrier Reef. They have issued a report entitled Clear ... or present danger? Great Barrier Reef pollution report card and brochures such as Get active now to protect the Great Barrier Reef. This report received a great deal of media attention in Queensland and there was little by way of a proper critique of the accusations made against the sugar industry by the WWF. The WWF cherry pick sentences and paragraphs from research papers with which to support their rather extravagant claims. In a sensational fashion, which unfortunately has become the norm for WWF, they then publish the hotchpotch of selective quotes as fact, which is then channelled through the media to an unsuspecting public. Let me give an example of their extravagant claims and language:

quote.para: 28 million tonnes of sediment flows onto the reef each yearâthat's equivalent to 3.5 million dump trucks emptying a load of soil onto the Reef each year, or nearly 9,600 a day.

speech.para: That is certainly enough to grab a headline and to alarm anyone who reads it and takes it at face value. Unfortunately, there are no facts to back up that outrageous claim. When you read the material from reputable organisations such as the Australian Institute of Marine Science you find that in certain river systems such as the Burdekin there is little evidence to substantiate the WWF's extravagant claims. However, there have been those who have undertaken a critique of the WWF report card, one being Jennifer Marohasy, an environmental scientist, and the other being Dr Gary Johns, of the Institute of Public Affairs. They said that the WWF make no substantiation of their claims and that with little or no scientific validity the WWF have merely `filled in the blanks'.

Who or what are the WWF? What is their role and, more importantly, who funds them? That is a very good question but a very difficult one to answer. There are no financial statements available. Although I have written to the WWF asking for details of their financial backers, they refuse to divulge any details. What information regarding the organisation is available, though, indicates that in 1999 they had worldwide revenues of some $720 million, branches in 41 countries and in excess of 3,000 staff. It seems that their current US budget is $100 million, and they have set aside a similar amount for their worldwide reef campaign. In Australia they are headquartered in Sydney. There are four or five staff in the Brisbane office, which has been set up as part of the antifarming-proreef campaign. Certainly, judging by the glossy brochures which they distribute, the WWF clearly have a large budget to pursue their aims. The latest manifestation of their campaign is to distribute the Get active now to protect the Great Barrier Reef' kit to children in schools located in sugar towns in North Queensland. I hold up a postcard directed to the Prime Minister. It says:

quote.para: Dear Prime Minister
I am very concerned about the amount of pollution Australia is producing.
In particular, our appalling record on fossil fuel and other `greenhouse' emissions is contributing to the worldwide threat of global warming.
Many scientists believe that this is causing coral bleaching and that at the current rate of degradation, our own national icon, the Great Barrier Reef, could be dead within a matter of decades.
Can you please let me know what measures you are taking to avert this environmental disaster?

speech.para: We all agree that the Great Barrier Reef is a national icon. It is very significant, particularly in Queensland, and we all wish to preserve the Great Barrier Reef. However, there have been a number of extremely misleading statements by WWF, including in the postcard I have referred to.

I want to refer to a study into coral bleaching undertaken in the United States by Robert Buddemeier, a senior scientist and chief of the Geohydrology Section at Kansas Geological Survey. He says that coral bleaching is an adaptive mechanism. The final conclusion of his long report is probably of most interest to us. He says:

quote.para: We view bleaching as providing an opportunity for reshuffling, a potent adaptive mechanism that instantly creates a host-symbiont combination with features that may prove more robust under altered conditions.

speech.para: In layman's terms, this means that in coral bleaching, which is a breakdown of the relationship between the coral and its symbiotic algae, the zooxanthellae, the coral simply expels its algae or, as the report proposes, the algae may voluntarily leave the coral. The reality is that under stress, corals and algae decide to part companyâa little like landlords and some of their tenants. They invite in an algae that is far more robust and suitable to the conditions at the time, whether they be temperature or chemical or some other stimuli. Coral bleaching is no more significant than perhaps a human being developing a tan after being out in the sun for too long.

talk.start.para: âYou can read the study for yourself. It says that corals after this process are much more robust in the future. There it is; you are very welcome to read it. If you do not agree, that is fine. WWF are very good at putting out blanket statements. If they said that coral bleaching at present is subject to many scientific hypotheses, that would be a fair comment, and this is one of those hypotheses. However, to say that the reef will be dead in a few years is simply not right. In fact, coral bleaching does not indicate that a reef is dead; it indicates that it is going through an adaptive phase. Many corals, although not all, reactivate. However, some species do not.

speech.para: Returning to WWF and their claims, in their mission statement they state, `We base our work around sound science.' None of us would disagree with sound science. Unfortunately, the WWF do not do that. They certainly have the right to mount a campaign like anyone in the community, but they have a great responsibility to rely on scientific facts and on sound science. In my opinion and in the opinion of others, they have not done that. They are part of the old doom brigadeâthe sky is falling in. The paper put out by Marohasy and Dr Gary Johns states:

quote.para: It is understood that the WWF reef campaign has helped generate over 7,000 new supporters in Australia alone during 2001. The increase in WWF membership has come at the price of undermining community confidence in Queensland agriculture, in particular sugarcane growing and beef-grazing.

speech.para: The paper goes on to say:

quote.para: WWF may have played a useful role in saving the Panda from Mao's China, and the Siberian Tiger from the Soviets. But the Great Barrier Reef is arguably the best-protected coral reef in the world. The reason WWF suggests otherwise has more to do with raising its profile than protecting the reef.

speech.para: Hear, hear to that! In fact, it is about the three Ms. It is about membership and 7,000 new members, it is about media and getting the front page, and it is about money and getting donations. If only it was about what scientific organisations with integrity, such as the Australian Institute of Marine Science, which has been in existence for 25 years, and its director, Dr Stephen Hall, are about. So many of these other organisations believe in a win, win and in a cooperative, sustainable relationship between the industries along the Queensland coast and the Great Barrier Reef. It is possible for all of those to live together with sensible management practices and for the reef to flourish as well. As Dr Johns says, it is arguably one of the best managed reefs in the world. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn this grievance debate I wish to air my concerns that as individuals and collectively members of this place we have not done enough to raise its standing in the public's eyes. Much of the criticism that we bring on ourselves is deserved and it should cause us to assess the way in which we go about our business. I want tonight to highlight some of my concerns and perhaps suggest ways in which we can improve our relevance to those who view us from outside. It is simply not good enough for this place, in a modern physical surrounding, to do its business in the same way it was done back in 1901 when the federal parliament first started.

speech.para: One area that is not paid enough attention is that of the executive government coming into this place and announcing its policies. I want to assure my colleagues on the opposite side that this is something that both sides of the political fence should take on board because both sides are guilty. But it will take the efforts of allânot only members of the executive but non-executive members from both the opposition and the governing partiesâto bring about change to the culture of this place.

I believe that there should be a greater use of ministerial statements. It is interesting to see what the House of Representatives Practice says about the use of ministerial statements. On page 255, in the paragraph about ministerial statements by leave, it simply concludes:

quote.para: Ministerial statements are not an everyday occurrence and their frequency has decreased in recent years.

speech.para: Regrettably, the statistics about the number of ministerial statements that we have had progressively over the years are fairly chilling. In 1996, there were 23; in 1997, 25; in 1998, eight; in 1999, 15; in 2000, seven; and, in 2001, four. Again, I do not wish to quote those statistics in a partisan way, even though I have taken a point in time that would suggest I was doing that. Simply put, I believe that we have gone away from having a full discussion and debate about policy matters.

I wish to contrast us with the British situation. It is very interesting that at present people from the United Kingdom believe that they have an executive government that is ignoring the parliament. But I find that an interesting analysis because when we compare it to our situation they do so many things that reinforce the importance of their parliament much better. For instance, in the post September 11 period the parliament was recalled on three occasions, and it happened at a time of recess. The parliament was recalled on three occasions to hear a ministerial statement from the Prime Minister about those events.

Not only is this comparison about the fact that the parliament was recalled but it is about the nature of the discussion and the way in which those ministerial statements were handled. There was a much fuller debate than we usually allowâeven though after a ministerial statement we would at least allow the opposition spokesperson to make a statement and usually we would allow a notation of the ministerial statement. For instance, last week there was a fuller debate in the Main Committee about the ministerial statement to do with events in East Timor. In the House of Commons there is a debate where not only the opposition spokesperson gets involved but a number of members of the House of Commons get involved. When comparing the nature of the debate, at the end of the discussion of the ministerial statement in the House of Commons there is a question period in which questions can be asked of the Prime Minister or of the minister who made the ministerial state about the content of the ministerial statement. The importance of this is that those questions are in the context of a very different culture in the way in which members of the House of Commons actually interact in debate.

Here in Australia we have set pieces. Everybody is guilty of it. We come in here and we have a set time of 20 minutes; somebody gets up on the other side and has a set time of 20 minutes. Very rarely is there an exchange or interchange based on ideas. But the culture of the House of Commons allows, through their standing orders, active interventionâthey can ask if the member on his own feet would allow interruption. That culture has allowed a much more civil interaction between the members. This is illustrated by the fact that at the end of a ministerial statement they then allow questioning. Questions about the detail of the ministerial statement would get a civil response and they would then proceed. I think that these are important cultural points of difference between the Australian parliament and the United Kingdom parliament that we really should be picking up on.

One of my bugbearsâand perhaps I am a bit partisan because I do use this minister as an example from time to timeâis that I wish that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs would come in here and make statements about the way in which we deal with and handle asylum seekers. Those statements could then lead to a fuller discussion on the floor of this chamber that might defuse the way in which the handling of asylum seekers is perceived in the public arenaâthe perception is perhaps 80 per cent punishment and 20 per cent compassion. We could be seen to be trying to come to grips with this as an issue. In the House of Commons, since October last year there have been two ministerial statements on the handling of asylum seekers.

I will again go through the elements of a ministerial statement made in the House of Commons: the minister comes in and gives the ministerial statement and, as in Australia, notice of that ministerial statement will have been given to the opposition. In Australia the opposition spokesperson would then get up and make comment. But in the House of Commons the discussion continues and other members get an opportunity to speak to the ministerial statement. Other members get an opportunity to ask questions about the ministerial statement of the minister, who remains in the chamber. If you look at their Hansard record, you will find that when the minister cannot stay for the full discussion of the ministerial statement the first thing they do is apologise to the House and give reasons for their not remaining. This is what is required. It is almost a quantum leap to imagine that we, as non-executive members of this place, would ask those who form the executive and are members of this chamber to take the chamber seriously.

As I said from the outset, I understand it is not just one political party doing this; it is something that has slowly got into the culture of this place. But I think that if we were to get back to having discussions and debates that were relevantânot just about legislation and about us being good legislators but on topics of interestâperhaps those who bother to observe us would see that we were more relevant and perhaps we could then encourage others who do not bother to observe us to take us for a serious chamber that ventilates our concerns and the concerns of the people we represent. Hopefully, there would be 150 different views. If we could deal with this as a proper cultural exchange that recognises that we can debate these issues in a civil manner without having to score points, I think we would be seen in a much better light by those we represent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI wish to grieve on behalf of the Australian people and the electors of Corangamite about the large increases in public liability insurance premiums. I raised this issue in a motion before the House today, and I wish to add to my remarks. We have a situation in Australia where legislators, business people and lawyers are following a `pot of gold' syndrome, and by that I mean that if you wish to receive a large payout you will sue and live in hope. The result of that is that volunteer groups and small business are now paying excessive premiumsâso much so that they are going out of business and those small voluntary groups are ceasing to operate in urban and rural Australia.

speech.para: What is the problem? What have we really got here when on some occasions insurance premiums are not able to be quoted? You cannot even get somebody to give you a quote for a premium for a particular activityâbe it in the building industry, be it in adventure tourism. That is a remarkable set of circumstances. Public liability premiums increased on some occasions by 30 per cent after 1 July. Most people are living in fear and trembling about that outcome. Other increases have been in the order of 300 per cent. In the longer run, of course, the community pays.

I would like to get a precise position of the debate as it now stands and read from the joint communique of the ministerial meeting of the Hon. Helen Coonan and the state ministers held on 27 March. I would just like to quote the major factors behind rising premiums and the reduced availability of public liability insurance that were identified. These were:
Â· changing community attitudes to litigation;
Â· change in the courts' view of what constitutes negligence;
Â· increased compensation payments for bodily injury claims;
Â· past under-pricing and poor profitability of the insurance industry;
Â· the collapse of HIH, a major player in the public liability market; and
Â· a decision by insurance companies to be more selective about the risks that they cover.

In a very complex world I think that covers the issues that I will speak about in a short while. One of the problems, of course, is the litigation culture that is now arising in Australiaâmore claims and a higher dollar value of the claims, so much so that people are encouraged by their lawyers to make a claim. We have a situation where advertising is now taking place in hospital wards for workers compensation. Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, you would be aware of that in your own electorate. We have the `no win, no fee' situation contributing to this whole argument. I strongly support the comments of the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, the Hon. Joe Hockey, both in this parliament and on 25 February 2002, when he said that the liability crisis was due to `an aggressive legal profession'. He went on to say:

quote.para: There's a very strong argument that the widespread reform of the legal profession in the last few years has failed and lawyers should not be able to advertise and not be able to provide services without charging.

speech.para: I strongly commend the minister's statement, and I think there is a lot to support that view. The legal profession are unhappy about that suggestion. We have the eminent authority of a former Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs AC KBE, who made this comment in an address to the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering:

quote.para: Some judges seem to strive to find a reason for finding in favour of a plaintiff, particularly if the injuries are serious, so that he or she may receive compensation ... The injured person does not put it down to bad luck, or blame himself, but blames someone who can be sued.

speech.para: I think that encapsulates the argument that many people out there in the cities and towns of Australia are concerned about, and that comes from someone who was formerly the highest legal authority in the land. The other factor, of course, has been the commercial pressures for insurers to increase their premiums. According to a JP Morgan-Deloitte 2002 survey, premiums have not kept up with inflation over the last 10 years. I quote from that report:

quote.para: On a CPI adjusted basis, premium rates in the commercial classes of business are still below their 1993 levels.

speech.para: If you read the literature, you will find that the competitive insurance companies have been trying to retain market share. They reduced their premiums and are unable to keep the capital sums and now they are seeing that they need to increase their premium prices. Reinsurance costs have also increased. And, of course, we had the catastrophe of September 11. Again I quote from the report on the same survey, which put it in a very clear manner:

quote.para: ... the events of September 11 forced insurers to focus on the premium rates they were charging for the risk being covered and determine whether the risk/reward position was appropriate.

speech.para: It very simple terms, the insurers found a new catastrophic position after September 11 that they had not considered and now they are moving their insurance rates forward. I would just like to quote a very interesting comment from Mr Julian Morris, Director of the International Policy Network in London, who made an interesting speech to the Centre for Independent Studies in Sydney. I quote from a report dated Wednesday, 6 March 2002 in the Australian. The headlineâwhich will strike a chord with many Australiansâ reads: `We are liable for ourselves'. I said in the earlier debate in this place that adventure tourism small operators are looking at the option at Mansfield of bringing about a set of arrangements whereby they can insure themselves in certain circumstances. The article says:

quote.para: Scrap negligence law and encourage self-insurance, argues Julian Morris.

speech.para: I would like to quote from the body of the article because I think it encapsulates the debate and the arguments I am putting forward to the House. The article states:

quote.para: But if the consumer pays the bill anyway, shouldn't he or she have a choice? Why not simply scrap the arcane system of negligence law and allow individuals to make whatever private contracts they like? Instead of relying on the courts or the government to set the price of compensation, we could all decide how much insurance cover we want and be free to buy whatever goods we wantâwith or without warranties. Producers would still be obliged to ensure that their products are fit for the purpose and are what they say they are. But they would no longer be obliged to attempt the impossible task of foreseeing all possible ways in which people might misuse their products and harm themselves.

speech.para: That clearly demonstrates the fundamental problem that whitewater rafting and equestrian businesses and some of those more dangerous sports such as parachuting face. They would be covered in a special set of circumstances, rather than being found at fault at the end of the day. Mr Morris went on to say:

quote.para: Imagine the consequences of such reform. Car manufacturers would not be held liable for injuries sustained in crashes caused by incompetent driving. The owners of cinemas would not be held liable for injuries sustained by people who forget how to use retractable seats. The producers of coffee would not be held liable for causing harm when a person spills their inherently hot beverage.

speech.para: They are quite simple examples. Another recent example that comes to mind is the huge payout to an individual who hit a sandbar which was deemed to be the responsibility of the local council.

We have a situation here in Australiaâ which all members of this House are concerned about, as the earlier debate indicatedâwhere we need to put forward some positive propositions so that Australia's way of life can continue. I genuinely believe that this is a major issue in the area of childbirth, where insurance premiums for gynaecologists are now at something like $40,000 to $50,000. What an amazing circumstance: that you have to have that sort of insurance premium to go about your daily business. I suggest that we ought to cap some of the particular claims, as we have done in workers compensation in Victoria, and that insurers might contest some of the public liability claims, as has been the case in Canada.

I commend the arguments to the House and to the public. I invite everyone to make a contribution to this very vexed issue, which really challenges the fundamental right of average Australians to go about their daily business without the fear of a major payout by way of premium and, when conducting their own business, the fear that they will be wiped out because of a massive payout well beyond their control because of the activities of the law and the way in which the situation arises. I hope that we do not reach the situation in America, where litigation has become the order of the day, and that we remain a free and open country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to talk about a recent report of the Economic Development Committee, a Victorian state government parliamentary committee, and its inquiry into the impact of structural changes in the Victorian economy. This particular inquiry encompassed a range of different issues. The terms of reference mentioned banking, in particular; postal communications; municipal services, including the reduction in the number of municipal outlets due to the recent municipal amalgamations; public transport; and employment services. The committee also assessed the impact of the withdrawal of the above services, including the reduction in the number of municipal outlets due to the recent municipal amalgamations on small and medium sized towns.

speech.para: The committee has seven members: three from the Labor Party, three from the Liberal Party and one from the National Party. Last month, the inquiry came down with a broad consensus and a range of findings and recommendations which, I believe, are certainly worth having a look at with respect to what could be done to deal with some of those issues that are faced in rural and regional areas. The chair of the committee, the Hon. Neil Lucas, is an opposition member of the upper house in Victoria and is a former local government chief executive in the Berwick area. In his foreword he said:

quote.para: Rural communities acknowledge that there will never be a return to the days of old. Rapid technological advancement and globalisation have forever changed the way in which services are delivered.

speech.para: The committee received some 61 written submissions, and approximately 110 people attended public hearings throughout Victoria. The committee came together with a consensus on all findings and recommendations contained within the report. As I mentioned earlier, the report covers a range of different areas of services that are seen to be absolutely crucial to the operation of small towns, in particular.

I would like to focus on the issue of banking services and some of the findings and recommendations which have come forth from this committee on this occasion. I stress that I do not think that some of the recommendations are practical or necessarily desirable and also I do not necessarily agree with some of the findings. With respect to trying to encourage some debate about the development, or lack of development, of these sorts of services currently in rural and regional areas, it is important to air some of those ideas and to get people thinking about what might be the way to go in the future.

When we talk about banking services in Australia, we can say that the banking industry has been facing up to some fairly massive technological changes, particularly in recent years. The increase in the levels of electronic banking and the withdrawal of face-to-face direct services not only in metropolitan areas but also in regional and rural areas has been significant. It has certainly created a good deal of passion and angst in the community. It has had quite a direct impact on the operation of rural and regional communities.

If you look at this report, you will find figures that have been provided by particular small towns and particular impact studies. For example, one of the figures relates to when a local branch closed and there was a drop of about 40 per cent in local business for butchers and a range of other services. I note that the member for Eden-Monaro on the other side is nodding his head, which he not often does when I speak, but on this issue I think he also has an understanding of the sorts of problems faced in those areas. When you look at some of the examples given, you see that branch closures is a severe problem. Although this report is about what is happening in Victoria, I do not think it is that different in other statesâin fact, in some areas in other states I think the problem is probably worse.

The findings and recommendations in the report cover a range of issues that are worthy of looking at for the future. There are some figures in this report which refer to the number of branch closures, and the number of branches that have gone in the past seven or eight years is phenomenal. Although there have certainly been technological advancements with Internet facilities and things like GiroPost and Australia Post that have improved accessibility post those closures, the fact of the matter is that it has altered the basic character of banking in a range of locations and that creates real problems for those communities in maintaining themselves. It has certainly created some real difficulties for them.

I have been a bit amazed by the lack of action by the government in respect of thisâ and we saw that most recently with the announcement by the National Australia Bank of the closure of some 56 agencies across the country. Ministers of the government have come out and said, `This is terrible.' The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Warren Truss, came out publiclyâhe put out a press release, as I recallâdecrying the fact that the National Australia Bank had done this and calling upon them to remember that they were a bank that had been built largely on rural investment and development and to take it into account. But words are cheap in this sort of exercise. The government has to look at taking some direct action to ensure that banks take into account the needs of those areas.

At the last election, the Labor Party went forward with a proposal for a social contract on banking services in rural areas in particular but also in general. The whole design of that was to try to ensure that there was certainty about service delivery, that we evaluated what was required for particular communities and in that way put a system in place which would ensure access to affordable banking services for all Australians. I urge the government to look at that again. It is one thing to say, as the Treasurer has on occasion, `Shop around.' It is one thing to say, as the minister for agriculture has, that the National Australia Bank is not really doing the right thing by the communities that helped build it. There is scope to take action, and that action ought to be taken by this government.

It is interesting to look at the recommendations in the report of the committeeâ which included members of the coalition in Victoriaâas they go across some of those issues. For example, one recommendation stated:

quote.para: The Committee recommends that following the announcement of a bank branch closure, the State Government assist affected communities by:

speech.para: Â· assessing the capacity of existing, alternative services and the appropriateness of these alternatives for specific target groups (elderly, disabled, unemployed, business customers); and

Â· providing a resource guide that facilitates the adoption of alternative banking methods, promotes the benefits of establishing and supporting a community bank through case studies of towns successful in overcoming bank branch closures and provides referrals to local, state and federal sources of assistance in acquiring and establishing alternative banking services.

There is a range of recommendations which go to the detail of what can be done to try to alleviate the concerns of particular communitiesânot necessarily to stand in the way of change but to try to ensure that aspects that occur around the question of those changes are done in a way which minimises disruption to communities that are already seeing it pretty tough.

Going beyond that, a range of other points is being made in this report. There is quite a deal of encouragement of community banking facilities, putting forward the view that in certain circumstances they will be quite successful, and there is a good deal of concern about the operation of the banks in a wider sense. Those points are worth making. There are also concerns about electronic banking and Internet services. It is one thing to say that they are part of the futureâand they certainly areâbut, when you are looking at the question of access to those sorts of facilities in rural and regional Australia, you see that that access is not as good as it is in metropolitan areas. I guess that comes back, in a range of ways, to the debate that has been going on particularly within the National Party regarding issues like the sale of Telstra, as proposed by the current government. When you look at some of these services and issues, it is clear that there is still a long way to go to ensure that the communities in rural and regional areas have a fair and reasonable level of service delivery.

I urge members to have a look at the report if they are concerned about these issues. It brings forward a range of concerns which people on this side of the House have been speaking about for some years. It certainly highlights the fact that over the last seven or eight years in particular those communities have had a massive gutting of services which is having an extremely detrimental effect on the operation of those communities and on the families, the Australians, the Howard battlers who live in those locations.

talk.start.para: â I do not think I need to remind anybody in this House about the problem that often exists in the community with regard to people's understanding of the various levels of governmentâwho is responsible for what. Every day of the week I am sure that all members of parliament have people come to their offices about matters which in fact are not the responsibility of the federal government but invariably are the responsibility of either the state government or local government. I find myself often having to give a bit of a history lesson to many people as to why it is that the federal government legally cannot involve itself in particular matters which people want you to fix because they have had no luck at the local or state level but which are, constitutionally, matters for the states and/or local government and not the federal government. The education about civics that was introduced into schools a few years ago is a great step forward so that more people in our community will grow up with an understanding of our three levels of government. I do not want to talk tonight about whether we should change that but it is something that I feel like debating at times. I am sure that every member in the House would agree with me on that matter.

speech.para: Meeting responsibilities is what I really want to talk about. When the federal government recently highlighted in the budget the fact that we needed to put more resources into defence because of various things happening internationally which require a greater defence commitment, we did not go around to the states and say, `We want you to throw in some money to keep our troops in Afghanistan or to protect our borders.' We took that responsibility. It is a federal responsibility, and we know what sorts of resources we have to place. The same should apply to those matters which are the responsibility of the states, but I find in my electorate that we are constantly having this debate, particularly when it relates to roads and education but also in relation to a whole heap of other services as well.

Because there are some grey areas, it seems that the states are able to exploit those grey areas and always when they get into some strife they want to pass the buck to the Commonwealth and say, `If the Commonwealth helped us out, we could solve this problem.' Really, it gets a bit rich when every time a state government finds itself in a bit of trouble it says that the easy way out is that you just say, `Come on, the Commonwealth can kick the can and help solve the problem.' What if we did that every time there was a responsibility which was quite rightly that of the federal government and we wanted to put more resources in? If we said to the states, `Come on, you come and help us,' they would quite rightly scream. So I think there needs to be an understanding of these responsibilities.

I want to mention a couple of things that are fairly typical of what is happening in my electorate in that respect. As for roads, down on the south coast of my electorate we have a problem at Pambula bridge on the Princes Highway. It is an old wooden bridge, it is low lying and every few years it floods, and that causes a great drama, particularly for the people around Eden if they want to get to the hospital, which is on the north side of the river that the bridge goes across in Pambula. The Princes Highway is quite clearly a state government road; it is not a part of the national highway system, therefore it is the responsibility of the state government.

The state government decided that they were going to spend some money and replace this bridge. But when it was discovered by the community that all they were going to do was build a new bridge in exactly the same location and at exactly the same level, the community said, `That's not going to solve too much. It's still going to flood just as often, so we are going to have the same problem.' But the state government were adamant that that was all they were going to do, and it was only after a lot of community jumping up and down that finally they said, `Oh, well, all right, we've listened to the community and you don't want that so we'll do something better, but it's going to cost a lot more money.' Instead of the $3 million-odd that they were going to spend, they said that a better solutionâa solution that they should have been working towards in the first placeâwas going to cost $10 million. So they said, `We'll put in five and we'll just ask the Commonwealth to put in five. It's not the Commonwealth's responsibility but we'll ask them anyway.' So this is the sort of example coming from the state government. If they were really taking their responsibilities properly, in their budget tomorrow they would have that bridge fully funded, because it is needed, it is on a major road down the coast and it is on a major state highway. If we are going to increase tourism and industry in that region, we need to know that the highways are going to be open all the time and they are going to be safe. So instead of just passing the buck and saying the Commonwealth can pay for it, they should live up to their responsibilities and do the right thing and spend the money that is required to fix that particular problem.

I am the first to say that I have said a number of times that the Princes Highway is gradually becoming more of a major highway and that if there is a way in which the Commonwealth can help at some particular time along the way then we will try to do so. But we have to remember that in 1991 there was an agreement between the Labor federal government of the day and the state governments that the federal government would only fund the national highway systemâ major highways between capital cities and between Sydney and Melbourneâthat is, the Hume Highwayâand that the state highways would be funded by the states. We have also introduced Roads of National Importance, and that is an opportunity to get a bit of extra funding into certain areasâand the Kiama bypass is an example of thatâand I hope that we can find some additional federal funds in the future for difficult locations. I will certainly be out there working to get that additional money, like I did to get some black spot fundingâabout $2 million has been spent on the Princes Highway in black spot fundingâand I will continue to work to find out about any other bits of the highway where we can help out, but the state government have to acknowledge their responsibilities for that particular piece of road.

Another example is the state government seeming in fact to be almost knocking back assistance over the Queanbeyan heavy vehicle bypass, also a state government responsibility. The federal government, acknowledging the importance of that bypass for the town of Queanbeyan, said that they would contribute $2 million towards it. We will put up $2 million towards the cost of about $5Â½ million, so you would think that the state government would jump at that and say, `You beauty! Here's a couple of million dollars we don't have to find.' But the state member for Monaro actually put questions on notice to the state transport minister about the Queanbeyan heavy vehicle bypass in which he said:

quote.para: Has the federal government committed $2 million to the Queanbeyan heavy vehicle bypass? Does this represent some 40 per cent of the total estimated cost to the project? Is the Queanbeyan City Council committed financially to the project? Have you met with the ACT minister for roads with regard to the cross-border aspects of this project? Will you be matching the federal commitment in the forthcoming budget to ensure this project goes ahead? As a commitment to the project was made by the state government in 1995 and the recent RTA cost-benefit analysis recommended the project proceed, what is causing the delay?

speech.para: All those legitimate questions on notice to the state minister for transport and what was his response? It was:

quote.para: The Queanbeyan bypass is an important project currently under consideration.

speech.para: Talk about the arrogance of the man! He gives that sort of answer to those six questionsâlegitimate questions to be asked. It is not good enough. The federal government is putting up $2 million for something that is really a state responsibility. The state government gave a commitment to it back in 1995. They should get on with it. Hopefully, they will do the right thing in tomorrow's budget and the money will be thereâthe rest of the moneyâso that this badly needed project can be done.

I am just about out of time, but the other example I was giving was with respect to education. Every time parents or P and Cs complain to the state government about extra funding, they say, `Go and talk to the federal government; they should give us some more.' Every time they get into strife, they use that particular excuse. In Eden-Monaro, the federal government has in fact been funding the greater proportion of all of the capital works for schools. As Brendan Nelson said, the federal budget last year increased funding to New South Wales by 5.2 per cent. Had the Carr government increased their budget by the same amountâthat is, 5.2 per centârather than the 2.5 per cent, they would have had an extra $145 million to spend. I call on them to increase their budget tomorrow. (Time expired)
