I applaud their efforts, and I will do everything in my power to make sure that they get their second phone.

talk.start.para: âLast week, I made some comments about what seems to be the demise of Blue Mountains District Hospital and I would like to continue those remarks. As I indicated then, for a number of years specialist services have been reduced or removed from Blue Mountains District Hospital at Katoomba. In spite of assurances to the contrary by the Wentworth Area Health Service, and in spite of assurances to the contrary by the New South Wales government, the latest sad tale in this saga of the demise of this hospital is recent announcements about the reduction in maternity services. We have had for some time a gradual reduction in obstetric services, partly because of the failure of the state government to attract support anaesthetist services to the hospital. There does not seem to have been enough effort on their part to get the obstetricians and the anaesthetists that we need to support those services.

speech.para: The latest development has been an announcement just two weeks ago by the health service that for the next six months maternity services will be totally suspended from Blue Mountains District Hospitalâno maternity services in the upper mountains for the next six months. This is an appalling situation and a total neglect of the needs of families in the upper Blue Mountains. The plan thenâif you could call it a planâis that, at the start of next year, the services will be partly resumed on a midwifery basis with no resident obstetrician. This raises, as I said last week, a number of very serious problems. What happens in the next six months? Over the next six months, every woman in the upper Blue Mountains who is about to give birth will have to travel to Nepean Hospital, a trip that would take an hour on a good day. With traffic congestion, as is frequently the case on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon, or in poor weather conditions, when it is fogbound, particularly during winter, the same trip could take an hour and a half to two hours. So we are asking women who are about to give birth to travel for up to an hour and a half or two hours to Nepean Hospital. There is no guarantee, with an early onset of labour, that they will be able to make that trip in time. The second problem is that Nepean Hospital is often overcrowded and too full. There is no guarantee that, in fact, if they get to Nepean, they can be taken care of at Nepean Hospital.

I started reading last week an email from a constituent who is in this exact position. His wife, having had two caesareans already, is due for a caesarean later this year. She can no longer have that caesarean at Blue Mountains District Hospital and has tried to book into Nepean Hospital. She cannot get in there and has to travel to Bathurst to have her child. This constituent in this email quite rightly makes a number of comments and asks questions. He states, `Across New South Wales, birthing units beyond those in major hospitals are being pressured to close,' that the closure of birthing units is not only a women's issue but a family issue, a father's issue, a men's issue, and that it is clearly evident that economic rationalism is driving health policy under the rhetoric of networking specialist services.

Unfolding now is the downgrading of rural hospitals, including Blue Mountains District Hospitalâeven though technically this is a metropolitan hospitalâto meet the heartless agenda of a social policy that sanctifies cost savings as a priority rather than communities and human lives. The constituent goes on to ask these questions: `Where is the evidence for rationalisation of these services; why hasn't any evidence been presented to this community; why has the community not been informed about these changes to its maternity unit; why are we a community, birthing our children, being forced to abdicate control and anticipate a perilous and dangerous journey down the mountain?' These are very valid questions. The Wentworth Area Health Service and the New South Wales government are badly failing the residents of the upper mountains. To expect them to make a trip of over an hour to have their child delivered is totally unacceptable.

The second question is: what happens next year? They are saying, `We will resume birthing at the Blue Mountains District Hospital next year, under a midwifery based model.' What happens if unexpected complications occur during childbirth? Somehow help will have to come from an hour and an half away or, if complications occur during birth, they will have to get the mother and child down to Nepean Hospital. That is just not safe for the mother, and it is not safe for child. Also, it is not fair to the residents of the upper Blue Mountains. I ask that the New South Wales government and the Wentworth Area Health Service take their responsibilities seriously. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe current level of concern about global warming and climate change can be said to have arisen from a conference held in Berkshire in the UK in May 1990. At that conference, hundreds of scientists gathered to put the finishing touches to the first scientific assessment report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changeâthe IPCC, as it has come to be known. Set up in 1998 by the United Nations General Assembly, the mission of the IPCC was to pool the opinions of as many scientists and policy experts as possible. It was to come up with a consensus report on the science of global warming, the probable impacts and the required policy responses. Margaret Thatcher attended that conference, and here is some of what she said:

quote.para: Today, with the publication of the report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, we have an authoritative early-warning system: an agreed assessment from some three hundred of the world's leading scientists of what is happening to the world's climate. They confirm that greenhouse gases are increasing substantially as a result of man's activities, that this will warm the Earth's surface with serious consequences for all of us.

speech.para: It was, she said, a report of historic significance.

Margaret Thatcher started her career as an industrial chemist. While the IPCC seemed like bad news, it could in fact have been much more frightening. Some conference members wanted the report to include worst case scenarios, including the possibility of a runaway, unstoppable greenhouse effect and the rapid melting of the polar ice caps, resulting in the flooding of the continental margins. Supporters of this view at the conference argued that governments routinely adopt this worst case strategy when dealing with defence budgets. Is this not the case in Australia at present, when the Treasurer claims that the sick, the disabled and the pensioners should be required to pay for defending our shores against the supposed hordes of illegal immigrants? Is the Treasurer not arguing from the worst case scenario in attempting to justify his budget? Why shouldn't we do the same thing for climate change? Surely it is a far more real threat than boatloads of desperate refugees.

In 1990, as a result of the IPCC report, the Labor cabinet committed Australia to a 20 per cent cut in greenhouse gas emissions by 2010. Under intense pressure from the Business Council of Australia, which was dominated by mining and oil industry companies, the government was forced to retreat from its progressive position. In 1991, the World Council of Churches issued a statement, which said:

quote.para: Concern for the protection of Creation is growing rapidly in the churches with global warming being a high priority.

speech.para: The churches said then that there was an urgent need for the industrialised nations to set specific targets and schedules to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. By 1996, and with the advent of the Howard government, Australia was leading the opponents to greenhouse gas emission reductions. The situation remains unchanged today, with the exception that Japan, formerly a staunch member of the so-called JUSCANZ groupâ Japan, United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealandâhas changed sides and is now supporting the reduction of emissions. Perhaps the group will soon be reduced to the US and Australia.

We are all aware of the mess that this government has made of the Australian insurance industry. How much worse will it become when the impact of global warming starts to affect Australia more directly? When Hurricane Andrew hit Florida in August 1992, the insurance bill topped $US16.5 billion, and then, in the same month, Cyclone Iniki hit Hawaii and Cyclone Omar hit Guam. Significant industry wide reinsurance price rises resulted. These increases have flowed on to the Australian insurance market and, no doubt, have been partly responsible for the recent insurance company failures. The insurance industry has been feeling the effects of climate change for more than 10 years now, yet this government has done nothing except complain about the cost of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Insurance has already been withdrawn from parts of the Caribbean and the Pacific Islands.

What should I say to one of my constituents if, after having their property destroyed in some wild storm, they find that their insurance company has either withdrawn its cover or collapsed because of the demand on the insurer's resources caused by climatic catastrophes? Will the government be prepared to bail out home owners trapped in this situation or will they be left in the same kind of limbo that now faces the medical profession? Australia's future prosperity will come not from a hole in the ground but from the efforts of hard working and dedicated people who are prepared to give their time and effort to developing new technologies, despite receiving almost no support from this government.

talk.start.para: âI, along with the international human rights groups around the world, call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister and this government to act to at least put Australia's view more forcefully and more firmly about the problems we are encountering in the Middle East. People may think, because it is no longer taking the first story on all our televisions, that nothing is happening and everything has subsided. Well, it has not. Mr Speaker, you have visited that area and you would know full well some of the problems that have been encountered by the Palestinians following the bombings that Israel has persistently continued to do over many months.

speech.para: I remember well in the previous parliament that we on the foreign affairs committee carried out a Middle East inquiry into what the problems were. One of the recommendations was that, within the near future, perhaps we as a country, along with other countries around the world, would have to recognise the rights of the Palestinians and perhaps grant, or work towards, them becoming an individual state in their own right.

I think what we have witnessed over the last 15 or 18 months has been absolutely appalling. The old city of Nablus, which has something like 3,000 years of history, has been bombed and destroyed, and the city of Bethlehemâwhere I have had the opportunity of walking through the Nativity scene and the areas of peaceâhas been destroyed. More particularly, I think what affected me mostâas I am sure it affected many other people who have had the opportunity of visiting the areaâwas to see the refugee camp in Jenin destroyed. I had gone through that area and sat down and spoken to doctors and teachers in the particular area. A doctor told us that, at one stage, he had something like 100,000 people with only him to look after them. Needless to say, the facilities he was using then have all gone because they have been completely bombed. We also talked to some of the teachers in the schools trying to provide education to the children in the refugee camps. They told us that they had to use the school for three sessions a day because there was no other way in which they could even try to educate to a minimum standard the children in those particular camps.

I think it is appalling that those people are the ones who are suffering. It is like all disagreements between countries that have the might, the tanks and the helicopters: those that use rocks, like the Palestinians, are the ones whose children, mothers and fathers are the innocent victims. They are the ones who have suffered through all this outrage. I believe that this country and this government should stand up and join the opposition in saying, `Enough is enough.' We should be united in what we are trying to do, and that is to see peace prevail in that areaâbut a peace that will be a long-lasting peace, a peace where the mighty do not get victory because they have overcome or downtrodden those who do not have the ability to fight back.

I, along with everybody else, was absolutely disgusted when we read about some of those bombers in different areas who disguise themselves and then go in and hit and kill innocent Israeli victims. There is no excuse for that. There is no excuse for murder of any description. But, at the same time, there is no excuse for a country as mighty as Israel, with the forces that it has behind it, to step through the Palestinian people and destroy them in the way that it has. To take away a man's pride is bad enough. To take away his home, to take away the food out of the mouths of his children, and then, more importantly, to destroy the schools, the hospitals and everything else that kept the community together, needs to be condemned. I think we as Australia, as a nation, need to stand up more forcefully, more vocally and condemn the actions that have occurred in the Middle East.

talk.start.para: to move:

motion.para: That this House:

interjection.para: (1) recognises that there is no Constitutional impediment to Commonwealth regulation of insurance claims procedures and the magnitude of insurance claims;

(2) recognises that the Commonwealth has the power to prescribe conditions upon which any person may carry out insurance business of any kind and establish any mechanisms for the supervision of such person and corporations and to regulate their affairs, under section 51(xiv) of the Constitution;
(3) recognises that the Commonwealth uses this power to regulate the Insurance Act 1973; the Life Insurance Act 1995 and the Insurance Contracts Act 1984;
(4) calls on the Commonwealth to order an inquiry by the Australian Law Reform Commission into the feasibility of a Commonwealth legislative scheme for the insurance industry; and
(5) calls on the Commonwealth to ensure that such an inquiry evaluate:

(a) whether the existing State-based scheme for negligence claims provides the most effective and efficient legal framework for the operation of such claims, in particular whether a Commonwealth-based operating structure should be provided for negligence claims;
(b) whether a Commonwealth-based operating structure could provide a uniform national insurance claim standard, with particular reference to:
(i) lump sum payment caps;
(ii) specific criteria for assessing disability;
(iii) standardising damages claims under all types of insurance including public liability, medical indemnity and compulsory third party;
(iv) the particular discrepancies that arise, especially in regard to damages awards, in different jurisdictions for similar injuries;
(v) whether existing types of negligence need to be amended, including moving from joint and severable liability towards proportional liability; and

(vi) whether it is possible for such legislation to apply to all insurance companies regulated under the Insurance Act 1973, the prudential legislation under the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority;
(c) the regulation of medical defence organisations as insurance companies;
(d) any constitutional limitations on implementing a Commonwealth-based regulatory structure;
(e) the costs and benefits of capping legal costs associated with negligence claims funded out of insurance policies; and

(f) the costs and benefits of changing the mode of insurance claim payment from lump sum to income stream, annuity or structured settlement, including consideration of any taxation issues and appropriate remedies.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the independent review of CASAs public relations performance during the Easter grounding of the Ansett 767 fleet that was announced by the then Chairman, Dr Paul Scully-Power in the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport legislation committee on 4 May 2001, has the appropriate public relations consultant been appointed; if so, who is it; if not, why not and when will the appointment be finalised.
(2) What criteria did or will CASA use to determine the appropriateness of the selected consultant.
(3) What is the timeframe advised to the consultant to complete the review.
(4) What are the terms of reference.
(5) What is the value, and particulars, of the contract with the consultant.
(6) Who will receive a copy of the consultants analysis and recommendations.
(7) Who will determine which recommendations will be implemented.
(8) Will the draft consultants report or the final report be released to the public, if so, how and when.
(9) What is the process to provide input to the review.
(10) Will public submissions be called.
(11) Will he have any involvement in the review or its implementation.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised the following:
(1) Gavin Anderson & Company has been appointed as the public relations consultant.

(2) At the request of the Board, CASA conducted a tender process to select a consultant to review CASA's public relations performance with respect to the recent Ansett incident. A selected tender process was used whereby a number of potentially suitable firms were invited to submit proposals. Each proposal was evaluated for suitability against a matrix of the following four criteria; personnel, risk, adequacy of methodology and relevant experience. From this evaluation, the successful consultant was chosen.
(3) The CASA Executive accepted the report in January 2002.

(4) The Terms of Reference for the review were contained in the selected tender process, and are reproduced as followsâThe Civil Aviation Safety Authority wishes to appoint a suitably qualified public relations firm to review its public relations performance during the recent events with Ansett. The review will seek to identify ways in which CASA's performance could be improved on an ongoing basis, particularly in similar circumstances to the Ansett matter.

The review should analyse the content of media statements by CASA and Ansett and the commentary of the media, to determine the appropriateness of CASA's media stance in contributing to the maintenance of public trust and confidence in Australia's system of aviation safety.
The review should include an assessment of the adequacy of CASA's public relations resources, the reporting lines and the positioning of CASA's Executive.

As a result of these reviews, a recommended public relations policy for CASA should be developed for managing similar issues in the future. The policy should have regard to the appropriateness of developing protocols with CASA's regulated entities relating to the release of information to the media.

(5) Funding allocated to the project totals $45,500-$47,500. The particulars of the agreed contract between CASA and Gavin Anderson & Company are Commercial-In-Confidence. CASA therefore does not believe that it would be appropriate to provide these details.
(6) The analysis and recommendations were provided to the CASA Board, the Director of Aviation Safety and the Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Promotion Division.
(7) The CASA Board, in consultation with the CASA Executive determined which recommendations will be implemented.
(8) It is not anticipated that the draft consultant's report or the final report will be made available to the public.

(9) Gavin Anderson & Company is interviewing a group of key stakeholders including Board members, senior management staff, aviation writers, political commentators, ministerial senior advisers, opposition spokesperson, industry and passenger representatives will be undertaken. These interviews are being conducted on a non-attributable basis with the aim of facilitating open and frank discussion.
(10) CASA does not anticipate that public submissions will be called.
(11) The review and its implementation is a matter for CASA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to his election funding commitments to the Scoresby Freeway and both the internal and external upgrades of the Hume Highway at Albury Wodonga, how many kilometres of the Hume Highway between Albury and Gundagai remain single carriageway.
(2) What is the cost to upgrade these sections to dual carriageway standard.
(3) How many trucks and cars travel on these sections each day.
(4) How many accidents, specifying any fatalities and injuries, have occurred in these sections in each of the past 5 years.
(5) What is the timetable to fund and complete the National Highway works required to upgrade these sections of the Hume Highway to dual carriageway standard.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) 105 kilometres of the Hume Highway in NSW is unduplicated. This comprises 88 kilometres south of the Sturt Highway junction through Albury to Wodonga, 1 kilometre at Gundagai (Sheahan Bridge) and 16 kilometres at Coolac, which is north of Gundagai.

(2) The NSW Roads and Traffic Authority (RTA) has estimated the cost of fully duplicating the Hume Highway at around $854 million. However, since there is limited planning along some sections, this is a strategic level estimate only and may be subject to significant change when further planning is undertaken.

(3) South of the Sturt Highway junction near Tarcutta, traffic levels average between 4,500-6,500 vehicles daily along the Hume Highway corridor. North of the Sturt Highway junction to Gundagai traffic levels are around 6,300-7,000 vehicles.

(4) Road traffic accidents are reported by local government area. Accidents and fatalities along the Hume Highway in the Gundagai, Wagga Wagga, Holbrook, Hume and Albury City Council areas for each of the past 5 years to 2000 (the latest data available) are:
(5) The Federal Government is committed to duplication of the Hume Highway in line with overall traffic needs, available funds and competing priorities.

The Government has made $0.2m available in 2001/02 for the RTA to further investigate the needs of the southern Hume, in light of local concerns about safety along certain sections of the Highway. Planning is also in progress for a dual carriageway bypass of Coolac and duplication of the Sheahan Bridge at Gundagai.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) In how many cases did the Migration Agents Regulation Authority caution or suspend migration agents in cases that clearly had no prospects of success.

(2) Are there regulatory requirements on the migration agent to tell the consumer whether there are grounds for success regarding an application; if so, what sanctions does the Authority have to prevent migration agents from lodging false or unfounded applications.
(3) Have complaints been made to the Authority about such cases; if so, (a) how many and (b) how long does it take the Authority to hear such cases.
(4) Has the Authority taken disciplinary action against migration agents that have not acted in good faith by falsely representing a case.
(5) In how many cases did migration agents avoid being sanctioned or prosecuted by de-registering themselves.
(6) Does the Authority publish the names of the agents that de-register; if not, why not.
(7) What measures are available to consumers in cases where an agent has de-registered.

(8) Of the 79 cases reported at page 23 of the Authority's 2000-2001 annual report as having no further action, (a) how many were subject to agents de-registering and (b) what advice is given to clients in these circumstances.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Since its inception in March 1998, the Migration Agents Registration Authority (MARA) has cautioned two migration agents and suspended one migration agent for their involvement in cases that clearly had no prospects of success.

(2) Registered migration agents are required by s.314(2) of the Migration Act 1958 to comply with the Migration Agents Code of Conduct that forms Schedule 2 of the Migration Agents Regulations 1998. The clauses that refer to the grounds for success regarding an application and the lodgement of false or unfounded applications are clauses 2.6, 2.7, 2.9 and 2.17. These state:

2.6 To the extent that a migration agent must take account of objective criteria to make an application under the Migration Act or Migration Regulations, he or she should be frank and candid about the prospects of success when assessing a client's request for assistance in preparing a case or making an application under the Migration Act or Migration Regulations.

2.7 An agent who is asked by a client to give his or her opinion about the probability of a successful outcome for the client's application should not hold out unsubstantiated or unjustified prospects of success when advising clients on applications under the Migration Act or Migration Regulations.

2.9 While a migration agent cannot be responsible for misinformation provided by a client, an agent must not make statements in support of an application under the Migration Act or Migration Regulations, or encourage the making of statements, which he or she knows or believes to be misleading or inaccurate.
2.17 If an application under the Migration Act or the Migration Regulations is vexatious or grossly unfounded (for example, an application that has no hope of success) the agent:
(a) must not encourage the client to lodge the application; and
(b) must advise the client that, in the agent's opinion, the application is vexatious or grossly unfounded; and
(c) if the client still wishes to lodge the applicationâmust obtain written acknowledgment of the client of the advice given under paragraph (b).

The Authority may issue sanctions against agents who fail to comply with the Code of Conduct. Those sanctions include a caution, a suspension, a cancellation or a refusal of the agent's re-registration application.

(3) (a) 139âsince the MARA's inception in March 1998. (b) The current average time being taken to finalise complaints is 87 days as complaints are not finalised until any appeals to either the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) or the Federal Court have been finally determined. This is because the Authority, under s.305 of the Migration Act 1958, can only publish a statement about the suspension or cancellation of an agent's registration once any such appeals have been finally determined.

(4) Since its inception in March 1998, the Authority has cancelled the registration of one migration agent, suspended the registration of two migration agents and cautioned one migration agent for making false or unfounded applications.

(5) Since the MARA's inception in March 1998, 20 migration agents have `de-registered' themselves or allowed their registration to lapse while complaints against their conduct were being investigated (this includes some agents who were subject to multiple complaints at the time).
(6) The Authority's publication powers do not extend to the publishing of the names of the agents who allow their registration to lapse or who `de-register' themselves.

Most migration agents who `de-register' do not do so to avoid sanction and the Authority would not want to imply that a negative connotation should be drawn towards them for `de-registering'. The creation of a listing of previously registered agents may also create confusion in the minds of consumers about the listing of currently registered agents.

(7) An agent who has `de-registered' or allows their registration to lapse, becomes an `inactive' agent. Where the Authority knows the name of an affected client, the Authority can request the inactive agent (under s.306D of the Migration Act 1958) to provide a copy to the Authority of the client's documents:
(i) that are or were connected with the giving, or anticipated giving, of that immigration assistance to those clients; and
(ii) if the documents relate to the affairs of that client.
Penalties can be applied under s.306H for non-compliance with such a request.
Where a migration agent has `de-registered' and seeks to be re-registered, any outstanding professional standards matters that had lapsed with their registration can be re-activated.

The Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 2002, which was reintroduced into Parliament on 14 February 2002, contains provisions that are aimed at preventing migration agents from avoiding the disciplinary provisions of the scheme by simply `de-registering' or allowing their registration to expire. If this Bill is passed, the Authority will be able to investigate complaints about `de-registered' migration agents, unless a complaint is received by the Authority more than 12 months after the registration ceased.

(8) (a) None of the 79 finalised complaints involved migration agents `de-registering'. Three complaints against agents who `de-registered' while subject to investigation by the Authority were deliberately not finalised to allow investigations to resume if the Migration Legislation (Migration Agents) Bill 2002 is passed. (b) Clients are advised that complaints will be reactivated if the migration agent seeks to be registered again or if their complaint could be reactivated if the Migration legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 2002 is passed. In addition, clients are currently advised that the Authority is not the only channel available to an individual to correct any perceived errors regarding advice given by a migration agent and that they may wish to consider seeking legal advice about other avenues.
